note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Theodor.
sp.l: _CAptaine, your friend's prefer'd, the Princeſſe has her,
Who, I aſſure my ſelfe, will uſe her nobly;
A prettie ſweet one 'tis indeed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Well bred Sir,
I doe deliver that upon my credit,
And of an honeſt ſtock.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo Captaine,
And no doubt will doe well.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Thanks to your care ſir;
But tell me Noble Colonell, why this habit
Of diſcontent is put on through the Army?
And why your valiant father, our great Generall,
The hand that taught to ſtrike, the Love that lead all;
Why he, that was the father of the warte,
He that begot, and bred the Souldier,
Why he ſits ſhaking of his Armes, like Autumne,
His Collours folded, and his Drums cas'd up,
The tongue of war for ever ty'd within us?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: It muſt be ſo: Captaine you are a ſtranger,
But of a ſmall time here a ſouldier,
Yet that time ſhewes ye a right good, and great one,
Elſe I could tell yee houres are ſtrangely alterd:
The young Duke has too many eyes upon him,
Too many feares 'tis thought too, and to nouriſh thoſe,
Maintains too many Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Turne their hearts,
Or turn their heeles up, heaven: 'Tis ſtrange it ſhould be.
The old Duke lov'd him dearely.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: He deſerv'd it;
And were he not my Father, I durſt tell yee,
The memorable hazzards he has run through
Deſerv'd of this man too; highly deſerv'd too;
Had they been leſſe, they had been ſafe Putskie,
And ſooner reach'd regard.

sp.speaker: Put
sp.l: There you ſtrook ſure ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did I never tell thee of a vow he made
Some yeares before the old Duke dyed?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I have heard yee
Speake often of that vow; but how it was,
Or to what end, I never underſtood yet?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ile tell thee then: and then thou wilt finde the reaſon:
The laſt great Muſter, ('twas before ye ſerv'd here,
Before the laſt Dukes death, whoſe honour'd bones
Now reſt in peace) this yong Prince had the ordering,
(To Crowne his fathers hopes) of all the Army:
Who (to be ſhort) put all his power to practiſe;
Faſhion'd, and drew 'em up: but alas, ſo poorely
So raggedly and looſely, ſo unſouldier'd,
The good Duke bluſh'd, and call'd unto my father,
Who then was Generall: Goe Archus ſpeedily,
And chide the Boy, before the ſouldier finde him,
Stand thou between his ignorance and them,
Faſhion their bodies new to thy direction;
Then draw thou up, and ſhew the Prince his errours.
My Sire obey'd, and did ſo; with all duty
Inform'd the Prince, and read him all directions:
This bred diſtaſte, diſtaſte grew up to anger,
And anger into wilde words broke out thus:
Well Archus, if I live but to command here,
To be but Duke once, I ſhall then remember,
I ſhall remember truely, truſt me, I ſhall,
And by my Fathers hand; the reſt his eyes ſpoke.
To which my Father anſwer'd (ſomewhat mov'd too)
And with a vow he ſeal'd it: Royall ſir,
Since for my faith and fights, your Icorne and anger
Onely purſue me; if I live to that day,
That day ſo long expected to reward me,
By his ſo ever noble hand you ſwore by,
And by the hand of Juſtice, never Armes more
Shall rib this body in, nor ſword hang here, ſir:
The Conflicts I will doe you ſervice then in,
Shall be repentant prayers. So they parted.
The time is come; and now you know the wonder.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I finde a feare too, which begins to tell me,
The Duke will have but poore and ſlight defences
If his hot humour raigne, and not his honour:
How ſtand you with him, Sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A perdue Captaine,
Full of my fathers danger.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: He has rais'd a young man,
They ſay a ſlight young man, I know him not,
For what deſert?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Beleeve it, a brave Gentleman,
Worth the Dukes reſpect, a cleere ſweet Gentleman,
And of a noble ſoule: Come, let's retire us,
And wait upon my father, who within this houre
You will finde an alter'd man.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't ſir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 2.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Is't not a handſome wench?

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.l: She is well enough, Madam:
I have ſeen a better face, and a ſtraiter body,
And yet ſhe is a pretty Gentle-woman.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What thinkſt thou Peteſca?

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Alas, Madam, I have no skill, ſhe has a black eye,
Which is of the leaſt too, and the dulleſt water;
And when her mouth was made, for certaine Madam,
Nature intended her a right good ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: She has a good hand.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: 'Tis good enough to hold faſt.
And ſtrong enough to ſtrangle the neck of a Lute.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What thinke ye of her colour?

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: If it be her owne
'Tis good black bloud: right weather-proofe
I warrant it.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: What a ſtrange pace ſhe has got?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: That's but her breeding.

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: And what a manly body? me thinks ſhe looks
As though ſhe would pitch the Barre, or goe to Buffets.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: Yet her behaviour's utterly againſt it,
For me thinks ſhe is too baſhfull.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Is that hurtfull?

sp.speaker: 2 Wo.
sp.l: Even equall to too bold: either of 'em Madam
May doe her injurie when time ſhall ſerve her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You diſcourſe learnedly, cal in the wench. Ex. Gent.
What envious fooles are you? Is the rule generall,
That women can ſpeak handſomely of none,
But thoſe they are bred withall?

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: Scarce well of thoſe Madam,
If they believe they may out-ſhine 'em any way:
Our natures are like oyle, compound us with any thing,
Yet ſtil we ſtrive to ſwim o'th' top:
Suppoſe there were here now,
Now in this court of Moſco, a ſtranger Princeſſe,
Of bloud and beauty equall to your excellence,
As many eyes and ſervices ſtuck on her;
What would you think?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I would thinke ſhe might deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: Your grace ſhall give me leave not to believe ye;
I know you are a woman, and ſo humourd:
Ile tell yee Madam, I could then get more gownes on ye,
More caps & feathers, more ſcarfs, & more ſilk ſtockings,
With rocking you a ſleep with nightly railings
Upon that woman, then if I had nine lives
I could weare out: by this hand ye'would ſcratch her eyes out.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Thou art deceiv'd foole; Enter Gentlewom. and Alinda.
Now let your own eyes mock ye.
Come hither girle: hang me & ſhe be not a handſom one.

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: I feare it will prove indeed ſo.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Did you ever ſerve yet
In any place of worth?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No Royall Lady.

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: Hold up your head; ſie.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Let her alone, ſtand from her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It ſhall be now,
Of all the bleſſings my poore youth has pray'd for,
The greateſt and the happieſt to ſerve you;
And might my promiſe carrie but that credit
To be believ'd, becauſe I am yet a ſtranger,
Excellent Lady, when I fall form dutie,
From all the ſervice that my life can lend me,
May ever-laſting miſerie then finde me.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What think ye now? I doe believe, and thank ye;
And ſure I ſhall not be ſo farre forgetfull,
To ſee that honeſt faith die unrewarded:
What muſt I call your name?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alinda Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Can yee ſing?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little, when my griefe will give me leave, Lady.

sp.speaker: Olm.
sp.l: VVhat griefe canſt thou have wench?
Thou art not in love?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If I be Madam, 'tis onely with your goodneſſe;
For yet I never ſaw that man I ſighed for.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Of what yeares are you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My mother oft has told me,
That very day and houre this land was bleſt
With your moſt happy birth, I firſt ſaluted
This worlds faire light: Nature was then ſo buſie,
And all the Graces to adorne your goodneſſe,
I ſtole into the world poore and neglected.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Something there was, when I firſt look'd upon thee,
Made me both like and love thee: now I know it;
And you ſhall find that knowledge ſhall not hurt you:
I hope ye are a Maid?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I hope ſo too, Madam;
I am ſure for any man: and were I otherwiſe,
Of all the ſervices my hopes could point at,
I durſt not touch at yours.

div.stage: Flouriſh. Enter Duke, Burris, and Gent.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The great Duke, Madam.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Good morow, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: A good day to your highneſſe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I am come to pray you uſe no more perſwaſions
For this old ſtubborne man: nay to command ye:
His ſaile is ſwell'd too full: he is grown too inſolent,
Too ſelf-affected, proud: thoſe poore ſlight ſervices
He has done my father, and my ſelf, has blowne him
To ſuch a pitch, he flyes to ſtoop our favours.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I am ſorry ſir: I ever thonght thoſe ſervices
Both great and noble.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: However, may it pleaſe yee
But to conſider 'em a true hearts ſervants,
Done out of faith to you, and not ſelfe-fame:
But to conſider royall ſir, the dangers;
When you have ſlept ſecure, the mid-night tempeſts,
That as he marcht ſung through his aged locks;
When you have ſed at full, the wants and famines;
The fires of heaven, when you have found all temperate,
Death with his thouſand doores—

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I have conſider'd;
No more: and that I will have, ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: For the beſt,
I hope all ſtill.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What handſome wench is that there?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: My ſervant, ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prethee obſerve her Burris.
Is ſhe not wondrous handſome? ſpeak thy freedome.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Shee appeares no leſſe to me ſir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Of whence is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Her father I am told is a good gentleman,
But farre off dwelling: her deſire to ſerve me
Brought her to th' Court, & here her friends have left her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She may find better friends:
Ye are welcome faire one,
I have not ſeen a ſweeter: By your Ladies leave:
Nay ſtand up ſweet, we'll have no ſuperſtition:
You have got a ſervant; you may uſe him kindly,
And he may honour ye: Exit Duke and Burris.
Good morrow ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good morrow to your Grace. How the wench bluſhes?
How like an Angel now ſhe looks?

sp.speaker: 1 VVom.
sp.l: At firſt jumpe
Jumpe into the Dukes armes? we muſt look to you,
Indeed we muſt, the next jump we are journeymen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I ſee the ruine of our hopes already,
Would ſhe were at home again, milking her fathers cows

sp.speaker: 1 Wo.
sp.l: I feare ſhee'll milke all the great Courtiers firſt.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: This has not made yee proud?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No certaine, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: It was the Duke that kiſt yee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Twas your brother,
And therefore nothing can be meant but honour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But ſay he love ye?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That he may with ſafety:
A Princes love extends to all his ſubjects.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But ſay in more particular?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pray feare not:
For vertues ſake deliver me from doubts, Lady:
'Tis the name of King, nor all his promiſes,
His glories, and his greatnſſe ſtuck about me,
Can make me prove a Traitor to your ſervice:
You are my Miſtris, and my noble Maſter,
Your vertues my ambition, and your favour
The end of all my love, and all my fortune:
And when I faile in that faith—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I beleeve thee,
Come wipe your eyes; I doe: take you example—

sp.speaker: Petſ.
sp.l: I would her eyes were out.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: If the winde ſtand in this doore,
We ſhall have but cold cuſtome: ſome trick or other,
And ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: Let me alone to think on't,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Come, be you neare me ſtill.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With all my duty. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Archas, Theodor, Putskie, Ancient, and Souldiers, carrying his armour peece-meale, his Colours wound up, and his Drums in Caſes.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: This is the heavieſt march we e're trod Captain,

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: This was not wont to be: theſe honour'd pieces
The fierie god of warre himſelfe would ſmile at,
Buckl'd upon that body, were not wont thus,
Like Reliques to be offer'd to long ruſt,
And heavy-ey'd oblivion brood upon 'em

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: There ſet 'em downe: and glorious war fare well;
Thou childe of honour and ambitious thoughts,
Begot in bloud, and nurſ'd with Kingdomes ruines;
Thou golden danger, courted by thy followers
Through fires and famines, for one title from thee,
Prodigall man-kinde ſpending all his fortunes;
A long farewell I give thee: Noble Armes,
You ribs for mighty mindes, you Iron houſes,
Made to defie the thunder-claps of Fortune,
Ruſt and conſuming time muſt now dwell with yee:
And thou good Sword that knewſt the way to conqueſt,
Upon whoſe fatall edge deſpaire and death dwelt,
That when I ſhooke thee thus, fore-ſhew'd deſtruction,
Sleep now from bloud, and grace my Monument:
Farewell my Eagle; when thou flew'ſt, whole Armies
Have ſtoopt below thee: At Paſſage I have ſeen thee,
Ruffle the Tartars, as they fled thy furie;
And bang 'em up together, as a Taſſell,
Upon the ſtreach, a ſtock of fearefull Pigeons.
I yet remember when the Volga curl'd,
The aged Volga, when he heav'd his head up,
And rais'd his waters high, to ſee the ruines,
The ruines out Swords made, the bloudy ruines;
Then flew this Bird of honour bravely, Gentlemen;
But theſe muſt be forgotten: ſo muſt theſe too,
And all that tend to Armes, by me for ever.
Take 'em you holy men; my Vow take with 'em,
Never to weare 'em more: Trophies I give 'em,
And ſacred Rites of warre to adorne the Temple:
There let 'em hang, to tell the world their maſter
Is now Devotions ſouldier, fit for prayer,
Why doe ye hang your heads? why look you ſad friends?
I am not dying yet.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Ye are indeed to us ſir.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Dead to our fortunes, Generall.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Youll finde a better,
A greater, and a ſtronger man to lead yee,
And to a ſtronger fortune: I am old friends,
Time, and the wars together make me ſtoop, gentlemen,
Stoop to my grave: my minde unfurniſh'd too,
Emptie and weak as I am: my poore body,
Able for nothing now but contemplation,
And that will be a taske too to a Souldier:
Yet had they but encourag'd me, or thought well
Of what I have done, I thinke I ſhould have ventur'd
For one knock more, I ſhould have made a ſhift yet
To have broke one ſtaffe more handſomly, and have dyed
Like a good fellow, and an honeſt ſouldier,
In the head of ye all, with my ſword in my hand,
And ſo have made an end of all with credit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Well, there will come an houre, when all theſe injuries
Theſe ſecure ſlights—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha! no more of that ſirrah,
Not one word more of that I charge ye.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I muſt ſpeak ſir.
And may that tongue forget to found your ſervice,
That's dumbe to your abuſes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Underſtand foole,
That voluntary I ſit downe.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: You are forced ſir,
Forced for your ſafety: I too well remember
The time and cauſe, and I may live to curſe 'em,
You made this vow, and whoſe un-nobleneſſe,
Indeed forgetfulneſſe of good—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more,
As thou art mine no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Whoſe doubts and envies—
But the devill will have his due.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Good yentle Colonell.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And though diſgraces, and contempt of honour
Reigne now, the wheele muſt turne againe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Peace ſirrah,
Your tongue's too ſaucy: doe ye ſtare upon me?
Downe with that heart, downe ſuddenly, down with it,
Downe with that diſobedience; tye that tongue up.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Tongue?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Doe not provoke me to forget my vow, ſirrah,
And draw that fatall ſword againe in anger.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: For heavens ſake, Colonell.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Doe not let me doubt
Whoſe Sonne thou art, becauſe thou canſt not ſuffer:
Doe not play with mine anger; if thou doſt,
By all the loyalty my heart holds—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I have done ſir,
'Pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I pray ye be worthy of it:
Beſhrew your heart, you have vext me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am ſorrie ſir.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Goe to, no more of this: be true and honeſt,
I know ye are man enough, mold it to juſt ends,
And let not my diſgraces; then I am miſerable,
When I have nothing left me but thy angers.

div.stage: Flouriſh. Enter Duke, Burris, Boroskie, Attend. & Gent.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: And't pleaſe ye ſir, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.l: Now, what's all this?
The meaning of this ceremonious Embleme?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your Grace ſhould firſt remember—

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: There's his nature.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I doe, and ſhall remember ſtill that injury,
That at the Muſter, where it pleas'd your greatneſſe
To laugh at my poore ſouldierſhip, to skorne it;
And more to make me ſeem ridiculous,
Took from my hands my charge.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O thinke not ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And in my Fathers ſight.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Heaven be my witneſſe
I did no more, (and that with modeſtie,
With love and faith to you) then was my warrant,
And from your Father ſeal'd: nor durſt that rudeneſſe
And impudence of ſcorne fall from my haviour,
I ever yet knew duty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We ſhall teach yee:
I well remember too, upon ſome words I told ye,
Then at that time, ſome angrie words ye anſwer'd,
If ever I were Duke, you were no ſouldier.
You have kept your word, and ſo it ſhall be to you.
From henceforth I diſmiſſe ye; take your eaſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I humbly thanke your Grace; this waſted body,
Beaten and bruis'd with Armes, dry'd up with troubles,
Is good for nothing elſe but quiet, now ſir,
And holy prayers; in which, when I forget
To thanke high heaven for all your bounteous favours,
May that be deafe, and my Petitions periſh.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: What a ſmooth humble cloak he has cas'd his pride in?
And how he has pull'd his clawes in? ther's no truſting—

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Speake for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Beleeve I ſhall doe ever.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To make yee vnderſtand we feele not yet
Such dearth of valour, and experience,
Such a declining age of doing ſpirits,
That all ſhould be confin'd within your Excellence,
And you, or none be honour'd, take Boroskie
The place he has commanded, lead the Souldier;
A little time will bring thee to his honour,
Which has been nothing, but the worlds opinion,
The ſouldiers fondneſſe, and a little fortune,
Which I believe his ſword had the leaſt ſhare in.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: O that I durſt but anſwer now.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Good Colonell.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My heart wil break elſe: Royal ſir, I know not
What you eſteem mens lives, whoſe hourely labours,
And loſſe of bloud, conſumptions in your ſervice,
Whoſe bodies are accquainted with more miſeries,
And all to keep you ſafe, then Dogs or ſlaves are.
His ſword the leaſt ſhare gain'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You will not fight with me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: No Sir, I dare not,
You are my Prince: but I dare ſpeake to yee,
And dare ſpeak truth, which none of their ambitions,
That be informers to you dare once thinke of;
Yet truth will now but anger yee: I am ſorry for't.
And ſo I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ev'n when you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sirrah, ſee me no more.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And ſo may you too:
You have a houſe ith' Countrey, keep you there Sir,
And when you have rull'd your ſelf, teach your ſon manners.
For this time I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Heaven forgive all:
And to your Grace a happie and long rule here.
And you Lord Generall, may your fights be proſperous.
In all your courſe, may Fame and Fortune Court you.
Fight for your Countrey, and your Princes ſafetie;
Boldly, and bravely face your enemie,
And when you ſtrike, ſtrike with that killing vertue,
As if a generall plague had ſeiz'd before ye;
Danger, and doubt, and labour caſt behinde yee,
And then come home an old and noble ſtorie.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: A little comfort ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As little as may be:
Farewell, you know your limit. Exit Duke, &c.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Alas, brave gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I doe, and will obſerve it ſuddenly:
My grave; I, that's my limit: 'tis no new thing,
Nor that can make me ſtart, or tremble at it,
To buckle with that old grim ſouldier now:
I have ſeen him in his ſowreſt ſhapes and dreadfull'ſt;
I, and I thanke my honeſtie, have ſtood him:
That audits caſt: Farewell my honeſt ſouldiers,
Give me your hands. Farewell, fare-well good Ancient,
A ſtout man, and a true, thou art come in ſorrow.
Bleſſings upon your ſwords, may they ne're faile yee.
You doe but change a man: your fortunes conſtant;
That by your ancient valours is ty'd faſt ſtill:
Be valiant ſtill and good; and when ye fight next,
When flame and furie make but one face of horror,
When the great reſt of all your honour's up,
When you would thinke a ſpell to ſhake the enemy,
Remember me: my prayers ſhall be with yee.
So once againe farewell.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Let's wait upon yee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, no, it muſt not be: I have now left me
A ſingle fortune to my ſelfe, no more,
Which needs no traine, nor complement: good Captain,
You are an honeſt and a ſober gentleman,
And one I thinke has lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: I am ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Look to my boy he's grown too head-ſtrong for me,
And if they think him fit to carrie Armes ſtill,
His life is theirs: I have a houſe ith' Countrey,
And when your better houres will give ye liberty
See me: you ſhall be welcome. Fortune to ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Ile cry no more, that will doe him no good,
And 'twill but make me drie, and I have no money:
Ile fight no more, and that will doe them harme;
And if I can do that I care not for money:
I could have curſt reaſonable well, and I have had the luck too
To have 'em hit ſometimes: Whoſoever thou art,
That like a devill didſt poſſeſſe the Duke
With theſe malitious thoughts; mark what I ſay to thee,
A plague upon thee, that's but the Preamble.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: O take the pox too:

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: They'll cure one another:
I muſt have none but kills, and thoſe kill ſtinking:
Or look ye, let the ſingle pox poſſeſſe them,
Or pox upon pox.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: That's but ill i'th' Armes ſir,

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Tis worſe ith' legs, I would not wiſh it elſe:
And may thoſe grow to ſcabs as big as Mole-hils,
And twice a day, the devill with a Currie-combe
Scratch 'em, and ſcrub em. I warrent him he has 'em.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: May he be ever lowzie.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That's a pleaſure,
The Beggars Leacherie: ſometime the Souldiers:
May he be ever lazie, ſtink where he ſtands,
And Maggots breed in's braines.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: I marrie ſir,
May he fall mad in love with his Grand-mother,
And kiſſing her, may her teeth drop into his mouth,
And one fall croſſe his throat, then let him gargell.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter? Enter a Post.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: Where's the Duke pray gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Keep on your way, you cannot miſſe.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: I thanke yee. Exit.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If he be married, may he dreame hee's Cuckol'd,
And when he wakes, believe, and ſweare he ſaw it:
Sue a divorce, and after finde her honeſt:
Then in a pleaſant Pigſty with his owne garters,
And a fine running knot, ride to the devill.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: If theſe would doe —

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Ile never truſt my minde more,
If all theſe faile.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: What ſhall we doe now Captaine?
For by this honeſt hand Ile be torne a pieces,
Unleſſe my old Generall goe, or ſome that love him,
And love us equall too, before I fight more:
I can make a ſhooe yet, and draw it on too,
If I like the legge well.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fight? 'tis likely.
No, there Will be the ſport boyes, when ther's need on's.
They thinke the other Crowne will doe, will carry us,
And the brave golden coat of Captain Cankro

sp.speaker: Boroskie:
sp.l: What a noyſe his very name carries?
'Tis gun enough to fright a nation,
He need no ſouldiers: if he doe, for my part,
I promiſe ye, he's like to ſeek 'em: ſo I thinke you thinke too,
And all the Army: No honeſt brave old Archas,
We cannot ſo ſoon leave thy memory,
So ſoon forget thy goodneſſe: he that does,
The ſcandall, and the ſcumme of Armes be counted.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: You much rejoice me: now you have hit my meaning:
I durſt not preſſe ye, till I found your ſpirits.
Continue thus.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.p: Ile goe and tell the Duke on't. Ent. 2. Poſt.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: No, no, hee'll finde it ſoone enough, and feare it,
When once occaſion comes: Another Packet.
From whence friend come yee?

sp.speaker: 2 Poſt.
sp.l: From the borders ſir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: What newes ſir, I beſeech yee?

sp.speaker: 2 Poſt.
sp.l: Fire and ſword gentlemen;
The Tartar's up, and with a mighty force,
Comes forward like a tempeſt, all before him
Burning and killing.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Brave boyes; brave newes boyes.

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Either we muſt have preſent helpe—

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Still braver.

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Where lyes the Duke?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Hee's there.

sp.speaker: 2 Poſt.
sp.l: 'Save ye gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We are ſafe enough, I warrant thee:
Now the time's come.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I now 'tis come indeed, and now ſtand firm boyes,
And let 'em burne on merrily.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: This City would make a marvelous fine bone-fire:
'Tis old dry timber, and ſuch wood has no fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Here will be trim piping anon and whining,
Like ſo many Pigs in a ſtorme,
When they heare the newes once, Enter Boroskie and Servant.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here's one has heard it already,
Room for the Generall.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Say I am falne exceeding ſick oth' ſuddain,
And am not like to live.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: If ye goe on Sir,
For they will kill yee certainly: they look for yee.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I ſee your Lordſhips bound, take a ſuppoſitory,
Tis I Sir; a poor caſt Flag of yours. The fooliſh Tartars
They burne and kill, and 't like your honour, kill us,
Kill with Guns, with Guns my Lord, with Guns Sir.
What ſayes your Lordſhip to a chick in ſorrell ſops?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Go, go thy wayes old true-peny;
Thou haſt but one fault, Thou art ev'n too valiant.
Come toth' Army gentlemen, and let's make them acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Away, we are for ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why whither run ye fools, wil ye leave my Lady?

sp.speaker: Peteſ.
sp.l: The Tartar comes, the Tartar comes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why let him,
I had thought you had feard no men: upon my conſcience
You have try'd their ſtrengths already: ſtay for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Shift for thy ſelfe Alinda. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Beauty bleſſe ye:
Into what Grooms Feather-bed will yee creep now?
And there miſtake the enemy: ſweet youths ye are,
And of a conſtant courage: are you afraid of foyning?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: O my good wench, what ſhall become of us?
The Poſts come hourely in, and bring new danger;
The Enemy is paſt the Volga, and beares hither
With all the blond and crueltie he carries,
My brother now will find his fault.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I doubt me.
Somewhat too late to Madam: but pray feare not,
All will be well I hope. Sweet Madam ſhake not.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How cam'ſt thou by this ſpirit? our Sex tremble.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am not unacquainted with theſe dangers:
And you ſhall know my truth; for e're you periſh,
A hundred ſwords ſhall paſſe through me: 'tis but dying,
And Madam we muſt doe it: the manner's all:
You have a Princely Birth, take Princely thoughts to ye,
And take my councell too; goe preſently,
With all the haſte yee have, (I will attend ye)
With all the poſſible ſpeed, to old Lord Archas,
He honours yee: with all your art perſwade him,
('I will be a diſmall time elſe) wooe him hither,
But hither Madam; make him ſee the danger;
For your new Generall looks like an Aſſe;
There's nothing in his face but loſſe.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Ile doe it,
And thank thee ſweet Alinda: O my Jewell.
How much I am bound to love thee: by this hand wench
If thou wert a man—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would I were to fight for yee.
But haſte deare Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I need no ſpurres Alinda. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The Lord Generall ſick now? is this a time
For men to creep into their beds? what's become Poſt
Of my Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: Beaten, and 't pleaſe your Grace.
And all his forces ſparkled.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: That's but cold newes. Enter a Gent.
How now, what good newes? are the ſouldiers ready?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes, ſir, but fight they wil not, nor ſtir from that place
They ſtand in now, unleſſe they have Lord Archas
To lead 'em out: they raile upon this Generall,
And ſing ſongs of him, ſcurvy ſongs to worſe tunes:
And much they ſpare not you ſir: here they ſweare
They'll ſtand and ſee the Citie burnt, & dance about it,
Unleſſe Lord Archas come before they fight for't.
It muſt be ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I could wiſh it ſo too:
And to that end I have ſent Lord Burris to him;
But all I feare will faile: we muſt dye gentlemen,
And one ſtroak wee'll have for't. Enter Burris.
What bringſt thou Burris?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That I am loath to tell: he will not come ſir.
I found him at his prayers: there he tells me,
The enemy ſhall take him, ſit for heaven:
I urg'd to him all our dangers, his owne worthes,
The Countries ruine: nay, I kneeld and pray'd him;
I ſe ſhooke his head, let fall a teare, and pointed
Thus with his finger to the ground; a grave
I think he meant; and this was all he anſwer'd.
Your Grace was much too blame.
Where's the new Generall?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: He is ſick poore man

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Hee's a poore man indeed Sir:
Your Grace muſt needs goe to the ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: They have ſent me word
They will not ſtirre: they raile at me,
And all the ſpight they have— Shout within. Enter Archas, Olimpia, and Alinda.
What ſhout is that there?
Is the enemy come ſo neare?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I have brought him Sir;
At length I have woo'd him thus farre.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Happy ſiſter;
O bleſſed woman!

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Uſe him nobly brother;
You never had more need: And gentlemen,
All the beſt powers yee have, to tongues turn preſently,
To winning and perſwading tongues: all my art,
Onely to bring him hither, I have utter'd;
Let it be yours to arme him: And good my Lord,
Though I exceed the limit you allow'd me,
Which was the happineſſe to bring ye hither,
And not to urge yee farther: yet, ſee your Countrey,
Out of your owne ſweet ſpirit now behold it:
Turne round, and look upon the miſeries,
Of every ſide the ſeares: ô ſee the dangers;
We finde 'em ſooneſt, therefore heare me firſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Next heare your Prince;
You have ſaid you lov'd him Archas,
And thought your life too little for his ſervice:
Thinke not your vow to great now, now the time is,
And now you are brought toth'teſt, touch right now ſouldier,
Now ſhew the manly pureneſs of thy mettle:
Now if thou beeſt that valued man, that vertue,
That great obedience teaching all, now ſtand it.
What I have ſaid forget, my youth was haſty,
And what you laid your ſelfe forgive, you were angry.
If men could live without their faults, they were gods Archas.
He weeps, & holds his hāds up: to him Burris.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have ſhew'd the Prince his faults:
And like a good Surgeon you have laid
Tha● to 'em makes 'em ſmart: hee feeles it,
Let 'em not ſeſter now ſir: your owne honour,
The bountie of that minde, and your allegeance,
'Gainſt which I take it, heaven gives no command ſir,
Nor ſeales no vow, can better teach ye now
What yee have to doe, then I, or this neceſſity:
Onely this little's left: would ye doe nobly,
And in the eye of honour truely triumph?
Conquer that minde firſt, and then men are nothing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Laſt, a poor virgin kneels: for loves ſake General,
If ever you have lov'd; for her ſake, ſir,
For your owne honeſty, which is a virgin,
Look up, and pitty us, be bold and fortunate.
You are a Knight, a good, and noble ſouldier,
And when your ſpurs were given ye, your ſword buckl'd,
Then were you ſworne for vertues cauſe, for beauties,
For chaſtity to ſtrike: ſtrike now, they ſuffer:
Now draw your ſword, or elſe you are recreant,
Onely a Knight ith' heeles, ith' heart a Coward:
Your firſt vow honour made, your laſt but anger.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How like my vertuous wife this thing looks, ſpeaks too?
So would ſhe chide my dulneſſe: faire one I thank yee:
My gracious ſir, your pardon, next your hand:
Madam, your favour, and your prayers: gentlemen,
Your wiſhes and your loves; and pretty ſweet one,
A favour for your Souldier.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Give him this wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thus doe I tye on victory.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My Armour,
My horſe, my ſword, my tough ſtaffe, and my fortune,
And Olin now I come to ſhake thy glorie.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Goe brave and proſperous, our loves go with thee.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Full of thy vertue, and our prayers attend thee.

sp.speaker: Bur. &c.
sp.l: Loden with victory, and we to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come home the ſon of honour,
And Ile ſerve ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Burris, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No newes of Archas yet?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But now, and't pleaſe ye
A Poſt came in, Letters he brought none with him,
But this deliver'd: He ſaw the Armies joyne,
The game of bloud begun, and by our Generall,
Who never was acquainted, but with Conqueſt,
So bravely fought, he ſaw the Tartars ſhaken,
And there he ſaid he left 'em.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where's Boroſkie?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: He is up againe, and't pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Sir, me thinks
This newes ſhould make yee lightſome, bring joy to ye,
It ſtrikes our hearts with generall comfort. Ex. Du.
Gone? What ſhould this meane, ſo ſuddenly?
Hee's well?

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: We ſee no other.
Would the reſt were well too,
That put theſe ſtarts into him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Ile goe after him.
'T will not be fit Sir: h'as ſome ſecret in him
He would not be diſturb'd in: know you any thing
Has croſt him ſince the Generall went?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not any.
If there had been, I am ſure I ſhould have found it;
Onely I have heard him oft complaine for money;
Money he ſayes he wants.
It may be that then.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: To him that has ſo many wayes to raiſe it,
And thoſe to honeſt, it cannot be. Enter Duke and Boroskie.
He comes back,
And Lord Boroskie with him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: There the game goes,
I feare ſome new thing hatching.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hether Burris,
Go ſee my Siſter, and commend me to her,
And to my litle Miſtriſſe give this token;
Tell her I'le ſee her ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes, I ſhall ſir. Ex. Bur and Gent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Waite you without: I would yet try him further.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Twill not be much amiſſe: has your grace heard yet
Of what he has done i'th' field?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Poſt but now
Came in, who ſaw 'em joyne, and 'has deliver'd,
The enemy gave ground before he parted.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, ſpeake thy mind man: 'tis not for fighting
And noiſe of War I keepe thee in my boſome;
Thy ends are nearer to me; from my childhood
Thou brought'ſt me up: and like another nature,
Made good all my neceſſities: ſpeake boldly.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir, what I utter, will be thought but envy
Though I intend, high heaven knows, but your honour,
When vaine and empty people ſhall proclaime me—
Good ſir excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do you feare me for your enemy?
Speake on your dutie.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then I muſt, and dare ſir.
When he comes home, take heed the Court receive him not,
Take heed he meet not with their loves, and praiſes,
That glaſſe will ſhew him ten times greater Sir,
And make him ſtrive to make good that proportion,
Then ere his fortune bred him, he is honourable,
At leaſt I ſtrive to underſtand him ſo,
And of a nature, if not this way poyſon'd,
Perfect enough, eaſie, & ſweet, but thoſe are ſoone ſeduc'd ſir;
He's a great man, and what that pill may worke,
Prepar'd by generall voyces of the people,
Is the end of all my councell: only this ſir,
Let him retire a while, there's more hangs by it
Then you know yet: there if he ſtand a while well,
But till the Souldier coole, who, for their ſervice
You muſt pay now moſt liberally, moſt freely,
And ſhewrd your ſelfe into 'em; 'tis the bounty
They follow with their loves, and not the bravery. Enter 2 Gent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But wher's the money? how now?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Sir the Collonell,
Son to the Lord Archas, with moſt happy newes
Of the Tartars overthrow, without here
Attends your graces pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Be not ſeen ſir,
He's a bold fellow, let me ſtand his thunders,
Toth' Court he muſt not come: no bleſſing here ſir,
No face of favour, if you love your honour. Enter Theo:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Do what you thinke is meeteſt; I'le retire ſir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Conduct him in ſir—welcome noble Collonell,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That's much from your Lordſhip: pray where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: We heare you have beat the Tartar.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is he buſie ſir?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Have ye taken Olin yet?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would faine ſpeake with him,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How many men have ye loſt?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do's he lye this way?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I am ſure you fought it bravely.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I muſt ſee him.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You cannot yet, ye muſt not, what's your Commiſ|ſion.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: No gentleman o'th' Chamber here?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why pray ye ſir?
Am not I fit to entertaine your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I thinke you are not ſir; I am ſure ye ſhall not.
I bring no tales, nor flatteries: In my tongue ſir,
I carry no fork'd ſtings.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You keepe your bluntneſſe.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd: it keeps me: I had felt elſe
Some of your plagues ere this: but good ſir trifle not,
I have buſineſſe to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: He's not well ſir,
And cannot now be ſpoke withall.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not well ſir?
How would he ha' been, if we had loſt? not well ſir?
I bring him newes to make him well: his enemie
That would have burnt his City here, and your houſe too,
Your brave gilt houſe, my Lord, your honours hangings,
Where all your Anceſtors, and all their battles,
Their ſilke and golden battles are deſcipher'd:
That would not only have abus'd your buildings,
Your goodly buildings ſir, and have drnnke dry your butteries,
Purlcin'd your Lordſhips plate, the Duke beſtow'd on you,
For turning hanſomely o'th toe, and trim'd your Virgins,
Trim'd 'em of a new cut, and't like your Lordſhip,
'Tis ten to one, your wife too, and the curſe is
You had had no remedy againſt theſe Raſcals,
No Law, and't like your honour; would have kil'd you too
And roaſted ye, and eaten ye, ere this time:
Notable knaves my Lord, unruly Raſcals:
Theſe youths have we tide up, put muzzels on 'em,
And pair'd their nailes, that honeſt civill Gentlemen,
And ſuch moſt noble perſons as your ſelfe is,
May live in peace, and rule the land with a twine thread.
Theſe newes I bring,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And were they thus deliver'd ye?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My Lord, I am no pen-man, nor no Orator,
My tongue was never oyl'd with Here and't like ye,
There I beſeech yee, weigh, I am a ſouldier,
And truth I covet onely, no fine termes ſir;
I come not to ſtand treating here; my buſineſſe
Is with the Duke, and of ſuch generall bleſſing—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You have overthrowne the enemy, we know it,
And we rejoyce in't; ye have done like honeſt ſubjects,
You have done handſomely and well.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: But well ſir?
But handſomly and well? what are we juglers?
Ile doe all that in cutting up a Capon.
But handſomely and well? does your Lordſhip take us
For the Dukes Tumblers? we have done bravely ſir,
Ventur'd our lives like men.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then bravely be it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: And for as brave rewards we look, and graces,
We have ſweat and bled for't ſir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And ye may have it,
If you will ſtay the giving. Men that thank themſelves firſt,
For any good they doe, take off the luſtre,
And blot the benefit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Are theſe the welcomes,
The Bells that ring out our rewards? pray heartily,
Early and late, there may be no more enemies:
Doe my good Lord, pray ſeriouſly, and ſigh too,
For if there be—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They muſt be met, and fought with.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: By whom? by you? they muſt be met & flattererd.
Why, what a devill aild ye to do theſe things?
With what aſſurance dare ye mocke men thus?
You have but ſingle lives, and thoſe I take it
A Sword may find too: why do ye dam the Duke up?
And choake that courſe of love that like a River
Should fill our empty veines againe with comforts?
But it ye uſe theſe knick knacks,
This faſt and looſe, with faithfull men and honeſt,
Youl be the firſt will find it.

div.stage: Enter Archas, Souldiers, Putskey, Ancient, and others,

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: You are too untemperate.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Better be ſo, and theeſe too, then unthankfull:
Pray uſe this old man ſo, and then we are paid all.
The Duke thanks ye for your ſervice, & the Court thanks ye,
And wonderfull deſirous they are to ſee ye;
Pray heaven we have roome enough to march for May-games,
Pageants, & bonfires for your welcome home Sir;
Here your moſt noble friend the Lord Boroskey,
A Gentleman too tender of your credit,
And ever in the Dukes eare, for your good Sir,
Crazie and ſickly, yet to be your ſervant,
Has leapt into the open aire to meet ye.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The beſt is your words wound not, you are welcome home Sir.
Hartily welcome home, and for your ſervice,
The noble overthrow you gave the Enemy,
The Duke ſalutes ye too with all his thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Sure they will now regard us.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: There's a reaſon:
But by the changing of the Colonels countenance,
The rolling of his eyes like angry billowes;
I feare the wind's not downe yet, Ancient.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is the Duke well Sir?

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Not much unhealthy,
Only a little grudging of an ague,
Which cannot laſt: he has heard, which makes him fearful,
And loath as yet to give your worth due welcome,
The ſickneſſe hath been ſomewhat hot i'th' Army,
Which happily may prove more doubt, then danger,
And more his feare then fate: yet howſoever,
An honeſt care—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye ſay right, and it ſhall be;
For though upon my life 'tis but a rumor,
A meere opinion, without faith or feare in't;
For Sir, I thanke heaven, we never ſtood more healthy,
Never more high and luſty; yet to ſatisfie,
We cannot be too curious or too carefull
Of what concernes his ſtate, wee'l draw away Sir,
And lodge at further diſtance, and leſſe danger.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: It will be well.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: It will be very ſcurvy.
I ſmell it out, it ſtinks abominably,
Stir it no more.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: The Duke Sir would have you too,
For a ſhort day or two, retyre to your owne houſe,
Whither himſelfe will come to viſit ye,
And give ye thanks.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I ſhall attend his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: A trick, a lowſie trick: ſo hoa, a trick boyes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How now, what's that?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I thought I had found a Hare Sir,
But 'tis a Fox, an old Fox, ſhall we hunt him?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more ſuch words.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: The ſouldier's growne too ſawcy,
You muſt tie him ſtraiter up.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I doe my beſt Sir;
But men of free-born minds ſometimes will flie out.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: May not we ſee the Duke?

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Not at this time Gentlemen,
Your Generall knowes the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We have no plague Sir,
Unleſſe it be in our pay, nor no pox neither;
Or if we had, I hope that good old Courtier
Will not deny us place there.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Certaine my Lord,
Conſidering what we are and what we have done;
If not, what need ye may have, 'twould be better,
A great deale nobler, and taſte honeſter
To uſe us with more ſweetnes; men that dig
And laſh away their lives at the Carts taile,
Double our comforts; meat, and their Maſters thanks too,
When they worke well, they have: Men of our qualitie,
When they doe well, and venture for't with valor,
Fight hard, lye hard, feed hard, when they come home Sir,
And know theſe are deſerving things, things worthy,
Can you then blame 'em if their minds a little
Be ſtirr'd with glory? 'tis a pride becomes 'em,
A litle ſeaſon'd with ambition,
To be reſpected, reckon'd well, and honour'd
For what they have don: when to come home thus poorly,
And met with ſuch unjointed joy, ſo looked on,
As if we had done no more but dreſt a horſe well;
So entertain'd, as if I thank ye Gentlemen,
Take that to drinke, had pow'r to pleaſe a ſouldier?
Where be the ſhouts, the bels rung out, the people?
The Prince himſelf?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Peace: I perceive your eye Sir
Is fixt upon this Captaine for his freedome,
And happily you find his tongue too forward;
As I am Maſter of the place, I carry,
'Tis fit I thinke ſo too, but were I this man,
No ſtronger tye upon me, then the truth
And tongue to tell it, I ſhould ſpeake as he do's,
And thinke with modeſtie enough, ſuch Saints
That daily thruſt their loves & lives through hazards,
And feareleſſe for their Countries peace, march hourely
Through all the doores of death, and know the darkeſt,
Should better be canoniz'd for their ſervice:
What labour would theſe men neglect, what danger
Where honour is, though ſeated in a billow,
Riſing as high as heaven, would not theſe ſouldiers,
Like to ſo many Sea-gods charge up to it?
Doe you ſee theſe ſwords? times Sithe was ne're ſo ſharp Sir;
Nor ever at one harveſt mow'd ſuch handfuls:
Thoughts ne're ſo ſudden, nor beliefe ſo ſure,
When they are drawne, and were it not ſometimes,
I ſwim upon their angers to allay 'em,
And like a calme depreſſe their fell intentions;
They are ſo deadly ſure, nature would ſuffer —
And whoſe are all theſe glories? why, their Princes,
Their Countries, and their Friends? Alas, of all theſe,
And all the happy ends they bring, the bleſſings,
They only ſhare the labors, a little joy then,
And outſide of a welcome, at an upſhot
Would not have done amiſſe Sir; But howſoever
Between me and my duty, no crack Sir
Shall dare appeare: I hope by my example
No diſcontent in them: without doubt Gentlemen,
The Duke will both looke ſuddenly and truly
On your deſerts: Methinks 't were good they were paid Sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They ſhall be immediately; I ſtay for mony;
And any favour elſe—.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We are all bound to ye;
And ſo I take my leave Sir; when the Duke pleaſes
To make me worthy of his eyes—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Which will be ſuddenly,
I know his good thoughts to ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: With all duty,
And all humility, I ſhall attend Sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Once more you are welcome home: theſe ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be ſure we be: and hanſomely.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Waite you on me ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And honeſtly: no jugling.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Will ye come ſir? Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray do not doubt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: We are no Boyes. Exit. Enter a Gent. and 2 or 3 with money.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's money from the Duke, and 't pleaſe your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How ſowre the Souldiers looke?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Is't told?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes: and for every company a double pay,
And the Dukes love to all.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That's worth a ducket.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You that be Officers, ſee it diſcharg'd then,
Why do not ye take it up?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: 'Tis too heavy:
'Body o'me, I have ſtrain'd mine arme.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Do ye ſcorne it?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Has your Lordſhip any dice about ye? ſit round Gentlemen.
And come on ſeaven for my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Do you thinke ſir,
This is the end we fight? can this durt draw us
To ſuch a ſtupid tameneſſe, that our ſervice
Neglected, and look'd lamely on, and skewd at
With a few honourable words, and this, is righted?
Have not we eyes and eares, to heare and ſee Sir,
And minds to underſtand the ſlights we carry?
I come home old, and full of hurts, men looke on me
As if I had got 'em from a whore, and ſhun me;
I tell my griefes, and feare my wants, I am anſwer'd,
Alas 'tis pity I pray dine with me on Sunday:
Theſe are the ſores we are ſicke of, the minds malladies,
And can this cure 'em? you ſhould have us'd us nobly,
And for our doing well, as well proclam'd us,
To the worlds eye, have ſhewd and fainted us,
Then ye had paid us bravely: then we had ſhin'd ſir,
Not in this gilded ſtuffe but in our glory:
You may take backe your money.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This I fear'd ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Conſider better Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Thanke your Lordſhip:
And now I'l put on my conſidering cap:
My Lord, that I am no Courtier, you may gueſſe it
By having no ſute to you for this money:
For though I want, I want not this, nor ſhall not,
Whilſt you want that civility to ranke it
With thoſe rights we expected; money growes ſir,
And men muſt gather it, all is not put in one purſe.
And that I am no Carter, I could never whiſtle yet:
But that I am a Souldier, and a Gentleman,
And a fine Gentleman, and't like your honour,
And moſt pleaſant companion: all you that are witty,
Come liſt to my ditty: come ſet in boyes,
With your Lordſhips patience. Song.
How do you like my Song, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Even as I like your ſelf, but 'twould be a great deale better,
You would prove a great deale wifer, and take this mony,
In your owne phraſe I ſpeake now ſir, and 'tis very well
You have learn'd to ſing; for ſince you prove ſo liberall, To refuſe ſuch meanes as this, maintaine your voice ſtill,
Twill prove your beſt friend.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſinging age ſir,
A merry moone here now: I'le follow it:
Fidling, and fooling now, gaines more then fighting.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: What is't you blench at? what would you aske? ſpeak freely.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And ſo we dare: a triumph for the Generall.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: And then an honour ſpeciall to his vertue.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That we may be prefer'd that have ſerv'd for it,
And cram'd up into favour like the worſhipfull,
At leaſt upon the Cities charge made drunke
For one whole year; we have done 'em ten yeares ſervice;
That we may enjoy our lechery without grudging,
And mine, or thine be nothing, all things equall,
And catch as catch may be proclaimed: that when we borrow,
And have no will to pay againe, no Law
Lay hold upon vs, nor no, Court controule us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Some of theſe may come to paſſe; the Duke may do 'em,
And no doubt will: the Generall will find too,
And ſo will you, if you but ſtay with patience: I have no power.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Nor will: come fellow Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray be not ſo diſtruſtfull.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: There are waies yet,
And honeſt waies; we are not brought up Starues.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: If your Lordſhip
Have any ſilke ſtockings, that have holes i'th'heeles,
Or ever an honourable Caſſock that wants buttons,
I could have cur'd ſuch malladies: your Lordſhips cuſtome
And my good Ladies, if the bones want ſetting
In her old bodies—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: This is diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Eight pence a day, and hard Eggs.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Troop off Gentlemen,
Some Coine we have, whilſt this laſts, or our credits,
Wee'll never ſell our Generalls worth for ſix-pence.
Ye are beholding to us.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fare ye well Sir,
And buy a pipe with that: doe ye ſee this skarfe ſir?
By this hand Ile cry Brooms in't, birchen Brooms ſir,
Before I eate one bit from your benevolence.
Now to our old occupations againe.
By your leave Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You will bite when ye are ſharper; take up the money.
This love I muſt remove, this fondnes to him,
This tenderneſſe of heart; I have loſt my way elſe.
There is no ſending man, they will not take it,
They are yet too full of pillage,
They'll dance for't ere't belong:
Come, bring it after. Enter Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now, refus'd their money?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Very bravely,
And ſtand upon ſuch termes 'tis terrible.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where's Archas?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Hee's retir'd Sir, to his houſe,
According to your pleaſure, full of dutie
To outward ſhew: but what within—

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Refuſe it?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Moſt confidently: 'tis not your revenewes
Can feed them ſir, and yet they have found a Generall
That knowes no ebbe of bountie: there they eate Sir,
And loath your invitations.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: 'Tis not poſſible,
Hee's poor as they.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You'll find it otherwiſe.
Pray make your journey thither preſently,
And as ye goe Ile open yee a wonder.
Good ſir this morning.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Follow me, Ile doe it.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Olimpia, Alindi, Burris, and Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But doe you thinke my brother loves her.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Certaine Madam,
He ſpeaks much of her, and ſometimes with wonder,
Oft wiſhes ſhe were nobler borne.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Doe you thinke him honeſt?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Your Grace is nearer to his heart, then I am,
Upon my life I hold him ſo.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: 'Tis a poore wench,
I would not have her wrong'd: methinks my Brother—
But I muſt not give rules to his affections;
Yet if he weigh her worth—

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You need not feare Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall not: Lord Burris
I love her well; I know not, there is ſomething
Makes me beſtow more then a care upon her:
I doe not like that ring, from him to her;
I meane to women of her way, ſuch tokens
Rather appeare as baits, then royall bounties:
I would not have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You will not find it,
Upon my troth I thinke his moſt ambition
Is but to let the world know 'has a hanſome Miſtris:
Will your Grace command me any ſervice to him?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Remember all my duty.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Bleſſings crowne ye:
What's your will Lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Anything that's honeſt;
And if you thinke it ſits ſo poore a ſervice,
Clad in a ragged vertue, may reach him,
I doe beſeech your Lordſhip ſpeake it humbly.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Faire one I will: in the beſt phraſe I have too,
And ſo I kiſſe your hand Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your Lordſhips ſervant.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Come hither wench, what art thou doing with that Ring.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am looking on the poſie, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The Jewels ſet within.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But where the joy wench,
When that inviſible Jewel's loſt? why doſt thou ſmile ſo?
What unhappy meaning haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nothing Madam,
But only thinking what ſtrange ſpels theſe Rings have,
And how they worke with ſome.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I feare with you too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This could not coſt above a Crowne.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twill coſt you
The ſhaving of your crowne, if not the waſhing.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But he that ſent it, makes the vertue greater.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I and the vice too Madam: goodnes bleſſe me:
How ſit 'tis for my finger.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: No doubt you'l find too
A finger fit for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sirrah, Peteſca,
What wilt thou give me for the good that followes this?
But thou haſt Rings enough, thou art provided:
Heigh ho, what muſt I doe now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You'l be taught that,
The eaſieſt part that e're you learn't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ay me, ay me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You will divide too, ſhortly,
Your voice comes finely forward.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Come hither wanton,
Thou art not ſurely as thou ſaiſt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would not:
But ſure there is a witchcraft in this Ring, Lady,
Lord how my heart leaps.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twill goe pit a pat ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And now methinks a thouſand of the Dukes ſhapes.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: Will no leſſe ſerve ye?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: In ten thouſand ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe the wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With eyes that will not be denide to enter;
And ſuch ſoft ſweet embraces; take It from me,
I am undone elſe Madam: I 'm loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What ailes the girle?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How ſuddenly I 'm alter'd?
And growne my ſelfe againe? doe not you feele it?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Weare that, and I'le weare this:
I'le try the ſtrengthon't.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How cold my bloud growes now?
Here's ſacred vertue:
When I leave to honour this,
Every houre to pay a kiſſe,
When each morning I ariſe,
Or I forget a ſacrifice:
When this figure in ray faith,
And the purenes that it hath,
I purſue not with my will,
Nearer to arrive at ſtill:
When I loſe, or change this Jewell,
I lie me faith, and heaven be cruell.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: You have halfe confirm'd me,
Keep but that way ſure,
And what this charme can doe, let me endure. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Archas, Theodore, 2 Doughters. Honora and Viola.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Carry your ſelfe diſcreetly, it concernes me,
The Duke's come in, none of your froward paſſions,
Nor no diſtaſtes to any: Prethee Theodor,
By my life, boy, 'twill mine me.

sp.speaker: The,
sp.l: I have done Sir,
So there be no foule play he brings along with him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What's that to you?
Let him bring what pleaſe him,
And whom, and how.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: So they meane well—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Is't ſit you be a Judge ſirrah,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis ſfit I feele Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Get a banquet ready,
And trim your ſelves up hanſomly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To what end?
Doe you meane to make 'em whores?
Hang up a ſigne then,
And ſet 'em out to Livery.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whoſe ſonne art thou?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yours Sir, I hope: but not of yonr diſgraces.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Full twenty thouſand men I have commanded,
And all their minds with this, calm'd all their angers;
And ſhall a boy of mine owne breed too, of mine owne bloud,
One crooked ſtick—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray take your way, and thrive in't,
I'le quit your houſe; if taint or black diſhonour
Light on ye, 'tis your owne, I have no ſhare in't.
Yet if it doe fall out ſo, as I feare it,
And partly find it too—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Haſt thou no reverence?
No dutie in thee?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This ſhall ſhew I obey ye:
I dare not ſtay: I would have ſhew'd my love too,
And that you aske as duty, with my life ſir,
Had you but thought me worthy of your hazzards,
Which heaven preſerve ye from, and keep the Duke too:
And there's an end of my wiſhes, God be with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stubborne, yet full of that we all love, honeſty,
Lord Burris, where's the Duke? Enter Burris.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: In the great chamber Sir,
And there ſtayes till he ſee you, ye 'have a fine houſe here.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A poore contented lodge, unſit for his preſence,
Yet all the joy it hath.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I hope a great one, and for your good, brave Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thanke ye Lord:
And now my ſervice to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I'le wait on ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Boroskey, Gent. and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May this be credited?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Diſgrace me elſe,
And never more with favour looke upon me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It ſeemes impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It cannot chuſe Sir,
Till your owne eies behold it; but that it is ſo,
And that by this meanes the too haughtie ſouldier
Has been ſo cramm'd and fed, he cares not for ye;
Beleeve, or let me periſh: Let your eyes
As you obſerve the houſe, but where I point it,
Make ſtay, and take a view, and then you have found it.

div.stage: Enter Archas, Burris, 2 Daughters and Servant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'le follow your direction: welcome Archas,
You are welcome home brave Lord, we are come to viſit ye,
And thanke ye for your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Twas ſo poore Sir,
In true reſpect of what I owe your Highneſſe,
It merits nothing.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are theſe faire ones yours Lord?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Their Mother made me thinke ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Stand up Ladies:
Beſhrew my heart they are faire ones; methinks fitter
The luſtre of the Court, then thus live darken'd:
I would ſee your houſe Lord Archas, it appeares to me,
A hanſome pile.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis neate but no great ſtructure;
I'le be your Graces guide, give me the keyes there.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Lead on, wee'l follow ye: begin with the Gallery,
I think that's one.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, and't pleaſe ye Sir,
The reſt above are lodgings all.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Goe on Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: The Duke gone thither, doe you ſay?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes marry doe I,
And all the ducklings too: but what the'l doe there.—

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I hope they'l crowne his ſervice.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: With a Cuſtard;
This is no weather for rewards; they crowne his ſervice?
Rather, they goe to ſhave his crowne: I was rated,
As if I had been a dog had worried ſheep, out of doores,
For making but a doubt.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: They muſt now grace him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Marke but the end.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I am ſure they ſhould reward him, they cannot want him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They that want honeſty, want any thing.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: The Duke is ſo noble in his owne thoughts.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That I grant ye,
If thoſe might only ſway him: but 'tis moſt certaine,
So many new borne ſlyes, his light gave life too,
Buzze in his beames, fleſh ſlies, and Butterflies,
Hornets, and humming Scarrabs, that not one honey Bee
That's loden with true labour, and brings home
Encreaſe, and credit, can ſcape rifling,
And what ſhe ſucks for ſweet, the turne to bitterneſſe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Shall we go ſee what they do, & talke our minds to 'em?

sp.speaker: 'P.
sp.l: That we have done too much, & to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Shall we be hang'd for him?
I have a great mind to be hangd now
For doing ſome brave thing for him; a worſe end will take me
And for an action of no worth; not honour him?
Upon my conſcience even the devill, the very devill
(Not to belye him) thinkes him an honeſt man,
I am ſure he has ſent him ſoules any times theſe twenty yeares,
Able to furniſh all his fiſhmarket.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Leave thy talking
And come, let's go to dinner and drinke to him,
We ſhall heare more ere ſupper time: if he be honour'd,
He has deſerv'd it well, and we ſhall ſight for't:
If he be ruin'd, ſo, we know the worſt then,
And for my ſelfe I'le meet it.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I ne're feare it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Archas, Borosky, Burris, Gentlemen, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They are handſome roomes all, well contriv'd and fitted,
Full of covenience, the proſpects excellent.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now will your Grace paſſe downe, and do me but the honour
To taſte a Country banket?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What roome's that?
I would ſee all now; what conveyance has it?
I ſee you have kept the beſt part yet; pray open it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha? I misdoubted this: 'tis of no receipte ſir,
For your eyes moſt unfit—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I long to ſee it,
Becauſe I would judge of the whole peece: ſome excellent paintings,
Or ſome rare ſpoiles you would keep to entertaine me
An other time, I know.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: In troth there is not,
Nor any thing worth your ſight: below I have
Some fountaines, and ſome ponds.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would ſee this now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Borosky, thou art a knave; It containes nothing
But rubbiſh from the other roomes and unneceſſaries:
Wil't pleaſe you ſee a ſtrange Clocke?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This, or nothing: Little Trunke ready.
Why ſhould you barre it up thus with defences
Above the reſt, unleſſe it contain'd ſomething
More excellent, and curious of keeping:
Open't, for I will ſee't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The keyes are loſt ſir;
Do's your grace thinke if it were fit for you,
I could be ſo unmannerly?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will ſee it, and either ſhew it—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good ſir—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thanke ye Archas,
You ſhew your love abundantly,
Do I uſe to entreat thus? force it open,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That were inhoſpitable: you are his gueſt ſir,
And with his greateſt joy, to entertaine ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hold thy peace foole; will ye open it?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot.
I muſt not if I could.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Goe breake it open.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I muſt withſtand that force: Be not too raſh Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Unarme him firſt, then if he be not obſtinate,
Preſerve his life.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thanke your grace, I take it:
And now take you the keyes, goe in and ſee Sir;
There feed your eyes with wonder, and thanke that traytor,
That thing that ſels his faith for favor. Exit Duke.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Sir, what moves ye?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have kept mine pure: Lord Burris there's a Judas,
That for a ſmile will ſell ye all: a Gentleman?
The Devill 'has more truth, and has maintain'd it;
A whores heart more beliefe in't. Enter Duke.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's all this Archas?
I cannot blame ye to conceale it ſo,
This moſt ineſtimable treaſure.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nor doe I wonder now the ſouldier ſleights me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Be not deceiv'd; he has had no favor here Sir,
Nor had you knowne this now, but for that pickthank,
That loſt man in his faith, he has reveal'd it,
To ſuck a little honey from ye has betray'd it.
I ſweare he ſmiles upon me, and forſworne too,
Thou crackt, uncurrant Lord: I'le tell ye all Sir:
Your Sire, before his death, knowing your temper,
To be as bounteous as the aire, and open,
As flowing as the Sea to all that follow'd ye,
Your great mind ſit for war and glory, thriftily
Like a great husband, to preſerve your actions,
Collected all this treaſure: to our truſts,
To mine I meane, and to that long-tongu'd Lords there,
He gave the knowledge, and the charge of all this,
Upon his death-bed too: And on the Sacrament
He ſwore us thus, never to let this treaſure
Part from our ſecret keepings, till no hope
Of ſubject could relieve ye, all your owne waſted,
No help of thoſe that lov'd ye could ſupply ye,
And then ſome great exploit afoot; my honeſtie
I would have kept till I had made this uſefull;
I ſhew'd it, and I ſtood it to the tempeſt,
And uſefull to the end 'twas left: I am cozen'd,
And ſo are you too, if you ſpend this vainly;
This worme that crept into ye has abus'd ye,
Abus'd your fathers care, abus'd his faith too:
Nor can this maſſe of money make him man more,
A ſtea'd dog has more ſoule, an Ape more honeſtie:
All mine ye have amongſt it, farwell that,
I cannot part with't nobler; my hearts cleare,
My conſcience ſmooth as that, no rub upon't,
But O thy hell.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ſeeke no heaven from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thy gnawing hell Boroskey, it will find thee:
Would ye heape coles upon his head has wrong'd ye,
'Has ruin'd your eſtate? give him this money,
Melt it into his mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What little Trunck's that,
That there o'th' top, that's lockt?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You'l find it rich Sir,
Richer I think then all.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You were not covetous,
Nor wour to weave your thoughts with ſuch a courſenes;
Pray racke not honeſtie.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Be ſure ye ſee it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring out the Trunck. Ent. with the Trunck.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You'l find that treaſure too,
All I have left me now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's this a poore gowne?
And this a peece of Seneca?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes ſure Sir,
More worth then all your gold, yet ye have enough on't,
And of a Mine far purer, and more precious:
This ſels no friends, nor ſearches into counſels,
And yet all counſell and all friends live here Sir,
Betrayes no faith, yet handles all that's truſty;
Wilt pleaſe ye leave me this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: With all my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What ſayes your Lordſhip to't?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I dare not rob ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Poore miſerable men, you have rob'd your ſelves both;
This gown, and this unvalu'd treaſure, your brave Father,
Found me a childe at ſchoole with, in his progreſſe,
Where ſuch a love he tooke to ſome few anſwers,
Unhappie boyiſh toyes hit in my head then,
That ſuddenly I made him thus as I was;
For here was all the wealth I brought his Highnes:
He carried me to Court, there bred me up,
Beſtow'd his favours on me, taught me Armes firſt,
With thoſe an honeſt mind; I ſerv'd him truly,
And where he gave me truſt, I thinke I fail'd not;
Let the world ſpeake: I humbly thanke your Highnes,
You have done more, and nobler, eas'd mine age Sir;
And to this care, a faire quietus given:
Now to my Booke againe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have your wiſh Sir,
Let ſome bring off the treaſure.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Some is his ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: None, none my Lord: a poore unworthy reaper,
The harveſt is his graces.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thanke ye Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But will not you repent Lord? when this is gone,
Where will your Lordſhip?—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray take you no care ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do's your Grace like my houſe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Wondrous well Archas,
You have made me richly welcome.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I did my beſt ſir,
Is there any thing elſe may pleaſe your Grace?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your daughters
I had forgot, ſend them to Court.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I ſaid your daughters; ſee it done: I'le have 'em
Attend my ſiſter, Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thanke your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And ſuddenly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Through all the waies I dare,
I'le ſerve your temper, though you try me too far. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Theodor, Putskey, Ancient, and Servant.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I wonder we heare no newes.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Heere's your fathers ſervant,
He comes in haſte too, now we ſhall know all ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I am glad I have met you ſir; your father
Intreats ye preſently make haſte unto him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What newes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None of the beſt Sir, I am aſham'd to tell it,
Pray aske no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did not I tell ye Gentlemen?
Did not I propheſie? he is undone then.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Not ſo Sir, but as neare it —

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: There's no help now;
The Armye's ſcatter'd all, though diſcontent,
Not to be rallied up in haſte to help this.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Plague of the devill; have ye watch'd your ſeaſons?
We ſhall watch you ere long.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Farewell, there's no cure,
We muſt endure all now: I know what I'le doe. Ex. The. & Ser.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Nay there's no ſtriving, they have a hand upon us,
A heavy, and a hard one.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Now I have it,
We have yet ſome Gentlemen, ſome boyes of mettle,
(What, are we bob'd thus ſtill, colted, and carted?)
And one mad trick wee'l have to ſhame theſe vipers;
Shall I bleſſe 'em?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Farwell: I have thought my way too. Exit.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Were never ſuch rare cryes in Chriſtendome,
As Moſco ſhall affoord: wee'l live by fooling,
Now lightings gone, and they ſhall find & feele it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more: it muſt be ſo; do you think I would ſend ye
Your father, and your friend —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pray Sir be good to us,
Alas, we know no Court, nor ſeeke that knowledge;
We are content like harmles things at home,
Children of your content, bred up in quiet,
Only to know our ſelves, to ſeeke a wiſedome
From that we underſtand, eaſie, and honeſt;
To make our actions worthy of your honour,
Their ends as innocent as we begot 'em:
What ſhall we looke for Sir, what ſhall we learne there,
That this more private ſweetneſſe cannot teach us?
Vertue was never built upon ambition,
Nor the ſoules beauties bred out of braverie:
What a terrible Father would you ſeeme to us,
Now you have moulded us, and wrought our tempers
To eaſie and obedient waies, uncrooked,
Where the faire minde can never loſe, nor loiter,
Now to divert our Natures, now to ſtem us
Roughly againſt the tide of all this treaſure?
Would ye have us proud? 'tis ſooner bred, then buried;
Wickedly proud? for ſuch things dwell at Court Sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would you have your children learn to forget their father,
And when he dies dance on his Monument?
Shall we ſeeke vertue in a Sattin gowne,
Imbroider'd vertue? faith in a well-curl'd feather?
And ſet our credits to the tune of green ſleeves?
This may be done; and if you like, it ſhall be.
You ſhould have ſent us thither, when we were younger,
Our Maiden-heads at a higher rate, our Innocence
Able to make a Mart indeed: we are now too old Sir,
Perhaps they'l think too cunning too, and ſlight us,
Beſides we are altogether unprovided,
Unfurniſh'd utterly of the rules ſhould guide us:
This Lord comes licks his hand; and proteſts to me:
Compares my beauty to a thouſand fine things;
Mountaines, and fountaines, trees, and ſtars, and goblins;
Now have not I the faſhion to beleeve him,
He offers me the honourable curteſie,
To lye with me all night, what a miſerie is this?
I am bred up ſo fooliſhly alas I dare not,
And how madly theſe things will ſhew there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſend ye not,
Like parts infected, to draw more corruption;
Like Spiders to grow great, with growing evill:
With your owne vertues ſeaſon'd, and my prayers,
The card of goodnes in your minds, that ſhowes ye
When ye ſaile falſe; the needle touch'd with honour,
That through the blackeſt ſtormes, ſtill points at happines:
Your bodies the tall barks, rib'd round with goodnes;
Your heavenly ſoules the Pilots, thus I ſend you;
Thus I prepare your voyage, ſound before ye,
And ever as you ſaile through this worlds vanitie,
Diſcover ſholes, rocks, quickſands, cry out to ye,
Like a good Maſter tack about for honour:
The Court is vertue's ſchoole; at leaſt it ſhould be;
Nearer the Sun the Mine lies, the mettels purer:
Be it granted, if the Spring be once infected.
Thoſe branches that flow from him muſt run muddy;
Say you find ſome ſins there, and thoſe no ſmall ones,
And they like lazie fits begin to ſhake ye:
Say they affect your ſtrengths, my happy children,
Great things through greateſt hazards are atchiev'd ſtill,
And then they ſhine, then goodnes has his glory,
His Crowne faſt rivited, then time moves under,
Where, through the miſt of errors, like the Sun,
Through thicke and pitchie clouds, he breaks out nobly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, you have made me half a ſouldier,
I will to court moſt willingly, moſt fondly.
And if there be ſuch ſtirring things amongſt 'em,
Such travellers into Virginia,
As fame reports, if they can win me, take me:
I thinke I have a cloſe ward, and a ſure one;
A honeſt mind I hope, 'tis petticote-proofe,
Chaine proofe, and jewell-proof: I know 'tis gold proof,
A Coach and foure horſes cannot draw me from it:
As for your hanſome faces, and filed tongues,
Curl'd Millers heads; I have another word for them,
And yet I'le ſlatter too, as faſt as they doe,
And lye, but not as lewdly: Come, be valiant ſiſter,
She that dares not ſtand the puſh o'th' Court, dares nothing,
And yet come off ungraſed: Sir, like you,
We both affect great dangers now; & the world ſhall ſee
All glory lies not in mans victorie.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Mine owne Honora.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am very fearfull,
Would I were ſtronger built? you would have me honeſt?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Or not at all my Viola.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'le thinke on't,
For 'tis no eaſie promiſe, and live there;
Doe you thinke we ſhall doe well?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Why what ſhould aile us?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Certaine they'l tempt us ſtrongly: beſide the glory
Which women may affect: they are hanſome gentlemen,
Every part ſpeaks: nor is it one deniall,
Nor two, nor ten: from every looke we give 'em,
They'le frame a hope: even from our prayers, promiſes,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let 'em feed ſo, & be fat: there is no feare wench,
If thou bee'ſt faſt to thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall be:
And your example will work more. Enter Theod.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not want it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How doe you Sir, can you lend a man an Angell?
I heare you let out money.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Very well Sir,
You are pleaſantly diſpos'd: I am glad to ſee it,
Can you lend me your patience, and be rul'd by me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Is't come to Patience now?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is t not a vertue?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know not. I ne're found it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's becauſe
Thy anger ever knowes, and not thy judgement.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know you have been rifl'd.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nothing leſſe boy:
Lord what opinions theſe vaine people publiſh?
Rifl'd of what?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Study your vertue patience,
It may get Muſtard to your meat. Why in ſuch haſte ſir,
Sent ye for me?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For this end onely, Theodore,
To wait upon your ſiſters to the Court;
I am commanded they live there.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Toth' Court ſir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Toth' Court I ſay.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And muſt I wait upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis moſt fit yee ſhould, ye are their brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is this the buſineſſe? I had thought your mind ſir
Had been ſet forward on ſome noble action,
Something had truely ſtirr'd ye. Toth' Court with theſe?
