Why they are your daughters ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: All this I know ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The good old woman on a bed he threw.
Toth' Court?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Nor drunke as you are:
Drunke with your duty ſir: doe you call it duty?
A pox o' duty, what can theſe doe there?
What ſhould they doe? Can ye look Babies ſiſters
In the young Gallants eyes, & twirle their Band-ſtrings?
Can ye ride out to ayre your ſelves? pray ſir,
Be ſerious with me: doe you ſpeake this truely?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why didſt thou never heare of women
Yet at Court boy?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes, and good women too, very good women,
Excellent honeſt women: but are you ſure ſir,
That theſe will prove ſo?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: There's the danger brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: God a mercy wench, thou haſt a grudging of it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now be you ſerious ſir, and obſerve what I ſay,
Doe it, and doe it handſomely: goe with 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: With all my heart ſir; I am in no fault now;
If they be thought whores for being in my company;
Pray write upon their backs, they are my ſiſters,
And where I ſhall deliver 'em.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye are wondrous jocund,
But prethee tell me, art thou ſo lewd a fellow,
I never knew thee faile a truth,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am a ſouldier,
And ſpell you what that meanes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A Souldier?
What doſt thou make of me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your Pallat's downe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thanke yee ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come, ſhall we to this matter?
You will to Court?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If you will pleaſe to honour us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ile honour yee, I warrant: Ile ſet yee off
With ſuch a luſtre wenches: Alas poore Viola,
Thou art a foole, thou crieſt for eating white-bread:
Be a good huſwife of thy teares, and ſave 'em,
Thou wilt have time enough to ſhed 'em ſiſter.
Doe you weep too? nay then Ile foole no more.
Come worthy ſiſters, ſince it muſt be ſo,
And ſince he thinks it fit to trie your vertues,
Be you as ſtrong to truth, as I to guard yee,
And this old gentleman ſhall have joy of ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 3.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Burris take you ten thouſand of thoſe Crowns,
And thoſe two chaines of Pearle they hold the richeſt,
I give 'em yee.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I humbly thanke your grace;
And may your great example worke in me
That noble charity to men more worthy,
And of more wants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You beare a good minde Burris;
Take twenty thouſand now: Be not ſo modeſt,
It ſhall be ſo, I give 'em: goe, there's my ring for't.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.p: Heaven bleſſe your Highneſſe ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You are honeſt.

div.stage: Enter Alinda, and Putskie at doore.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: They're comming now to Court, as faire as vertue:
Two brighter ſtarres ne're roſe here.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Peace, I have it,
And what my Art can doe; the Duke—

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I am gone,
Remember. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am counſell'd to the full ſir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My prettie Miſtris, whither lyes your buſineſſe?
How kindly I ſhould take this, were it to me now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe immediately to your grace,
At this time.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have no addreſſe, I doe believe ye,
I would yee had.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: 'Twere too much boldneſſe Sir,
Upon ſo little knowledge, leſſe deſerving.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You'll make a perfect Courtier.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A very poore one.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A very faire one ſweet: come hither to me.
What killing eyes this wench has? in his glorie
Not the bright Sun, when the Sirian ſtarre reignes,
Shines halfe ſo fierie.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why does your grace ſo view me?
Nothing but common handſomeneſſe dwells here ſir,
Scarce that: your grace is pleas'd to mock my meanneſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not goe: I doe not lie unto thee,
In my eye thou appear'ſt—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Dim not the ſight ſir,
I am too dull an object.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Canſt thou love me?
Canſt thou love him will honour thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I can love,
And love as you doe too: but 'twill not ſhew well:
Or if it doe ſhew here where all light luſtres,
Tinſell affections, make a glorious gliſtering,
Twill halt ith' handſome way.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are yee ſo cunning?
Doſt think I love not truely?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, ye cannot,
You never travell'd that way yet: pray pardon me,
I prate ſo boldly to you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There's no harme done:
But what's your reaſon, ſweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would tell your grace,
But happily—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It ſhall be pleaſing to me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I ſhould love you again, & then you would hate me.
With all my ſervice I ſhould follow yee,
And through all dangers.

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: This would more provoke me,
More make me ſee thy worthes,
More make me meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You ſhould doe ſo, if yee did well and truely.
But though yee be a Prince, and have power in ye,
Power of example too, ye have fail'd and falter'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Give me example where?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You had a Miſtris,
Oh heaven, ſo bright, ſo brave a dame, ſo lovely,
In all her life ſo true.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That ſerv'd yee with that conſtancy, that care,
That lov'd your will, and woo'd it too.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That nus'rd your honour up, held faſt your vertue,
And when ſhe kiſt encreas'd, not ſtole your goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And I neglected her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Loſt her, forſook her,
Wantonly ſlung her off.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What was her name?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her name as lovely as her ſelfe, as noble,
And in it all that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What was it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her name was Beau-deſert:
Doe you know her now ſir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Beau-deſert? I not remember—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I know you doe not:
Yet ſhe has a plainer name; Lord Archas ſervice;
Do you yet remember her? there was a Miſtris
Fairer then women, far fonder to you ſir,
Then Mothers to their firſt-borne joyes: Can you love?
Dare you profeſſe that truth to me a ſtranger,
A thing of no regard, no name, no luſtre,
When your moſt noble love you have neglected,
A beautie all the world would wooe and honour?
Would you have me credit this? thinke ye can love me,
And hold ye conſtant, when I have read this ſtorie?
Is't poſſible you ſhould ever favour me,
To a ſlight pleaſure prove a friend, and faſt too,
When, where you were moſt ty'd, moſt bound to benefit,
Bound by the chaines of honeſty and honour,
You have broke and boldly too? I am a weak one,
Arm'd onely with my feares: I beſeech your Grace
Tempt me no further.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who taught you this Leſſon?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Woefull experience Sir: if you ſeek a faire one,
Worthy your love, if yet you have that perfect,
Two daughters of his ruin'd vertue now
Arive at Court, excellent faire indeed ſir,
But this will be the plague on't, they'r excellent honeſt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I love thy face.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Upon my life yee cannot.
I doe not love it my ſelfe Sir, 'tis a lewd one,
So truely ill Art cannot mend it; 'ſod if 'twere handſome,
At leaſt if I thought ſo, you ſhould heare me talke ſir
In a new ſtraine; and though ye are a Prince,
Make ye Petition to me too, and wait my anſwers;
Yet o' my conſcience I ſhould pitty yee,
After ſome ten yeares ſiege.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prethee doe now.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What would ye doe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why I would lye with yee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I doe not think yee would.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Introth I would wench.
Here, take this Jewell.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Out upon't that's ſcurvee.
Nay, if we doe, ſure wee'll doe for good fellowſhip,
For pure love, or nothing: thus you ſhall be ſure ſir
You ſhall not pay too deare for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sure I cannot.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: By'r Lady but yee may: when ye have found me able,
To doe your work well, ye may pay my wages.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why does your Grace ſtart back?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I ha' ſeen that ſhakes me:
Chills all my bloud: O where is faith or goodneſſe?
Alinda thou art falſe, falſe, falſe thou faire one,
Wickedly falſe; and (woe is me) I ſee it.
For ever falſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am glad't has taken thus right. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ile goe aske my Lady, ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whether I ſhall lye with ye, or no: If I find he— willing—r
For look ye ſir, I have ſworn, while I am in her ſervice—
('Twas a raſh oath I muſt confeſſe.)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou mockſt me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, would yee lye with me, if I were willing?
Would you abuſe my weakneſſe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would peece it,
And make it ſtronger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I humbly thank your highneſſe,
When you piece me, you muſt piece me to my Coffin:
When you have got my Maiden-head, I take it,
'Tis not an inch of an Apes taile will reſtore it;
I love ye, and I honour yee, but this way
Ile neither love nor ſerve yee:
Heaven change your minde ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And thine too:
For it muſt be chang'd, it ſhall be. Exit.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Boroskie, Burris, Theodore, Viola, and Honora.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They are goodly gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are,
Wondrous ſweet women both.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Does your Lordſhid like 'em?
They are my ſiſters ſir; good luſty Laſſes,
They'll doe their labour well, I warrant yee
You'll finde no bed-ſtraw here ſir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thanke yee brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is not ſo ſtrongly built: but ſhe is good mettle,
Of a good ſtirring ſtraine too: ſhe goes tith ſir. Enter 2. Gent.
Here they be gentlemen muſt make ye merry,
The toyes you wot of: doe you like their complexions?
They be no Moors: what think ye of this hand gentlemen?
Here's a white Altar for your ſacrifice:
A thouſand kiſſes here. Nay, keep off yet gentlemen,
Let's ſtart firſt, & have fair play: what would ye give now
To turne the globe up, and finde the rich Moluccas?
To paſſe the ſtraights? here (doe ye itch) by St. Nicolas,
Here's that will make ye ſcratch and claw,
Claw my fine Gentlemen, move ye in divers ſorts:
Pray ye let me requeſt yee, to forget
To ſay your prayers, whilſt theſe are Courtiers;
Or if yee needs will thinke of heaven, let it be no higher
Then their eyes?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How will ye have 'em beſtow'd ſir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Even how your Lordſhip pleaſe,
So you doe not bake 'em.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Bake 'em.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: They are too high a meat that way, they run to gelly.
But if you'l have 'em for your own dyet, take my counſel,
Stew 'em between two feather-beds.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Pleaſe you Colonell
To let 'em wait upon the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes ſir,
And thanke your honour too: but then happily,
Theſe noble Gentlemen ſhall have no acceſſe to 'em,
And to have 'em buy new cloathes, ſtuddy new faces,
And keep a ſtinking ſtirre with themſelves for nothing,
'Twill not be well y'faith: they have kept their bodies,
And bin at charge for Bathes: do you ſee that ſhirt there?
Way but the morall meaning, 'twill be grievous:
Alas, I brought 'em to delight theſe gentlemen,
I weigh their wants by mine: I brought 'em wholſome,
Wholſome, and young my Lord, and two ſuch bleſſings
They will not light upon againe in ten yeare.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: 'Tis fit they wait upon her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are fit for any thing.
They'll wait upon a man, they are not baſhfull,
Carrie his cloak, or untie his points, or any thing,
Drink drunk, and take Tobacco; the familiarſt fooles—
This wench will leap over ſtools too, & ſound a Trumpet,
Wraſtle, and pitch the Bar; they are finely brought up,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ladies, ye are bound to your brother,
And have much cauſe to thank him:
Ile eaſe ye of this charge, and to the Princeſſe,
So pleaſe you, Ile attend 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thank your Lordſhip:
If there be e're a private corner as yee goe Sir,
A fooliſh lobbie out oth' way, make danger,
Trie what they are, trie.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are a merrie gentleman.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would faine be your honours kinſeman.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are to curſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Farewel wenches, keep cloſe your ports, y'are waſht elſe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Brother beſtow your fears where they are needfull.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Honor thy name is, and I hope thy nature.
Goe after, Gentlemen, goe, get a ſnatch if you can,
Yond'old Erra Pater will never pleaſe 'em.
Alas I brought 'em for you, but ſee the luck on't,
I ſweare I meant as honeſtlie toward ye—
Nay doe not crie good gentlemen: a little counſell
Will doe no harme: they'll walke abroad ith' evenings,
Ye may ſurprize 'em eaſily, they weare no Piſtols.
Set downe your mindes in Metre, flowing Metre,
And get ſome good old linnen woman to deliver it,
That has the trick on't: you cannot faile:
Farewell gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have frighted off theſe fleſh-flies.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Fleſh-flies indeed my Lord. Enter a Serv.
And it muſt be verie ſtinking fleſh they will not ſeize on.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip bid me bring this Casket.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes. Good Colonell
Commend me to your worthy father, and as a pledge
He ever holds my love, and ſervice to him,
Deliver him this poore, but hearty token,
And where I may be his—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ye are too noble;
A wonder here my Lord, that dare be honeſt,
When all men hold it vitious: I ſhall deliver it,
And with it your moſt noble love. Your ſervant. Ex. Bur.
Were there but two more ſuch at Court, 'twere Sainted,
This wil buy brawn this Chriſtmas yet, & Muſcadine. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Ancient, crying Broomes, and after him ſeverally, foure Souldiers, crying other things. Boroskie and Gent. over the Stage obſerving them.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Broom, Broom, the bonnie Broom,
Come buy my Birchen Broom,
Ith' warres we have no more room,
Buy all my bonnie Broom.
For a kiſſe take two;
If thoſe will not doe,
For a little, little pleaſure,
Take all my whole treaſure:
If all theſe will not do't,
Take the Broom-man to boot.
Broom, Broom, the bonnie Broome.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: The wars are done and gone,
And Souldiers now neglected, Pedlers are,
Come maidens, come alone,
For I can ſhew you handſome, handſome ware.
Powders for, for the head,
And drinks for your bed,
To make yee blith and bonney.
As well in the night we ſouldiers can fight,
And pleaſe a young wench as any.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I have fine Potato's,
Ripe Potato's.

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.l: Will ye buy any Honesty, come away,
I ſell it openly by day,
I bring no forced light, nor no Candle
To cozen yee; come buy and handle:
This will ſhew the great man good,
The Tradeſ-man where he ſweares and lyes,
Each Lady of a noble bloud,
The Citie dame to rule her eyes:
Ye are rich men now: come buy, and then
Ile make yee richer, honeſt-men.

sp.speaker: 4 Sol.
sp.l: Have ye any crackt maiden-heads, to new leach or mend?
Have ye any old maiden-heads to ſell or to change?
Bring 'em to me with a little pretty gin,
Ile clout 'em, Ile mend 'em, Ile knock in a pin,
Shall make 'em as good maids agen,
As ever they have bin.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What means all this, why do y' ſel Brooms Ancient?
Is it in wantonneſſe, or want?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: The onely reaſon is,
To ſweep your Lordſhips conſcience: here's one for the nonce.
Gape ſir, you have ſwallowed many a goodlier matter—
The onely caſting for a crazie conſcience.

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip buy any honeſtie? 'twill be worth your money.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: 3 Sol.
sp.l: Honeſtie my Lord, 'tis here in a quill.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take heed you open it not, for 'tis ſo ſubtle,
The leaſt puffe of wind will blow it out oth' kingdome.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: Will your Lordſhip to taſte a fine Potato?
'Twill advance your wither'd ſtate.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fill your honour full of moſt noble itches,
And make Jack dance in your Lordſhips breeches.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: If your daughters on their beds,
Have bow'd, or crackt their maiden-heads;
If in a Coach with two much tumbling,
They chance to crie, fie, fo, what fumbling;
If her foot ſlip, and downe fall ſhee,
And break her leg 'bove the knee,
The one and thirtieth of Februarie let this be tane,
And they ſhall be arrant maids againe.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye are brave ſouldiers; keep your wantonneſſe,
A winter will come on to ſhake this wilfulneſſe.
Diſport your ſelves, & when you want your money— Ex.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Broom, Broom, &c. Exit ſinging.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You muſt not be ſo fearefull, little one,
Nor Lady you ſo ſad, you will ne're make Courtiers
With theſe dull ſullen thoughts; this place is pleaſure,
Preſerv'd to that uſe, ſo inhabited;
And thoſe that live here, live delightfull, joyfull:
Theſe are the Gardens of Adonis, Ladies,
Where all ſweets to their free and noble uſes,
Grow ever young and courted.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Bleſſe me heaven,
Can things of her yeares arrive at theſe rudiments?
By your leave fair gentlewoman, how long have you bin here?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith much about a week.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You have ſtudied hard,
And by my faith arriv'd at a great knowledge.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Were not you baſhfull at firſt?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I, I, for an houre or two:
But when I ſaw people laugh'd at me for it,
And thought it a dull breeding—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are govern'd here then
Much after the mens opinions.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ever Ladie.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And what they think is honourable.—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Moſt preciſely
We follow with all faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A goodly Catechiſme.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But baſhfull for an houre or two?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Faith to ſay true,
I do not think I was ſo long: for look yee,
Tis to no end here, put on what ſhape ye will,
And ſoure your ſelfe with ne're ſo much auſteritie,
You ſhall be courted in the ſame, and won too,
'Tis but ſome two houres more; and ſo much time loſt,
Which we hold pretious here: In ſo much time now
As I have told you this, you may loſe a ſervant,
Your age, nor all your Art can e're recover.
Catch me occaſion as ſhe comes, hold faſt there,
Till what you doe affect is ripn'd to yee.
Has the Duke ſeen yee yet?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What if he have not?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You doe your beauties too much wrong, appearing
So full of ſweetneſſe, newneſſe; ſet ſo richly,
As if a Councell beyond nature fram'd yee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If we were thus? ſay heaven had given theſe bleſſings,
Muſt we turne theſe to ſin-oblations?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How fooliſhly this Countrey way ſhewes in ye?
How full of flegme? doe you come here to pray Ladies.
You had beſt crie, ſtand away, let me alone gentlemen,
Ile tell my father elſe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This woman's naught ſure,
A verie naughtie woman.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Come, ſay on friend,
Ile be inſtructed by ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Either I or the devil ſhal: The Duke you were ſpeaking of.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembred: yes, let him firſt ſee you,
Appeare not openly till he has view'd yee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Hee's a very noble Prince they ſay.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O wondrous gracious;
And as you may deliver your ſelfe at the firſt viewing.
For look ye, you muſt beare your ſelfe; yet take heed
It be ſo ſeaſon'd with a ſweet humilitie,
And grac'd with ſuch a bountie in your beautie—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But I hope he will offer me no ill?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, no:
'Tis like he Will kiſſe ye, and play with ye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Plaie with me, how?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why, good Lord, that you are ſuch a foole now.
No harme aſſure your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Will ye play with me too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Look babies in your eyes, my prettie ſweet one:
Ther's a fine ſport: doe you know your lodgings yet?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I heare of none.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I doe then, they are handſome,
Convenient for acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Acceſſe?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes little one,
For viſitation of thoſe friends and ſervants,
Your beauties ſhall make choice of: friends and viſits:
Doe not you know thoſe uſes? Alas poore novice;
There's a cloſe Cowch or two, handſomely placed too.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What are thoſe I pray you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Who would be troubled with ſuch raw things? they are to lie upon,
And your love by ye; and diſcourſe, and toy in.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Alas I have no love.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You muſt by any meanes:
You'll have a hundred, feare not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Honeſtie keep me:
What ſhall I doe with all thoſe?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You'll finde uſes:
Ye are ignorant yet, let time work; you muſt learne too,
To lie handſomly in your bed a mornings, neatly dreſt
In a moſt curious VVaſtcoat, to ſet ye off well,
Play with your Bracelets, ſing you muſt learn to rhime to,
And riddle neatlie; ſtudie the hardeſt language,
And 'tis no matter whether it be ſenſe, or no,
So it goe ſeemlie off. Be ſure yee profit
In kiſſing, kiſſing ſweetly: there lies a maine point,
A key that opens to all practick pleaſure;
Ile helpe yee to a friend of mine ſhal teach ye,
And ſuddenlie: your Countrey way is fulſome.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have ye ſchooles for all theſe myſteries?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O yes,
And ſeverall houres prefix'd to ſtudie in:
Ye may have Kalanders to know the good houre,
And when to take a jewell: for the ill too,
VVhen to refuſe, with obſervations on 'em;
Under what Signe 'tis beſt meeting in an Arbor,
And in what Bower, and houre it works; a thouſand,
VVhen in a Coach, when in a private lodging,
VVith all their vertues.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Have ye ſtudied theſe?
How beaſtly they become your youth? how bawdily?
A woman of your tenderneſſe, a teacher,
Teacher of theſe lewd Arts? of your full beauty?
A man made up in luſt would loath this in yee:
The rankeſt Leacher, hate ſuch impudence.
They ſay the devill can aſſume heavens brightneſſe,
And ſo appeare to tempt us: ſure thou art no woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I joy to finde ye thus.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou haſt no tenderneſſe,
No reluctation in thy heart: 'tis miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All's one for that; read theſe and then be ſatisfi'd,
A few more private rules I have gather'd for ye,
Read 'em, and well obſerve 'em: ſo I leave ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A wondrous wicked woman: ſhame go with thee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What new Pandoras box is this? Ile ſee it,
Though preſently I teare it. Read Thine Viola,
'Tis in our owne wills to believe and follow.

body.l: Worthy Honora, as you have begun
In vertues ſpotleſſe ſchoole, ſo forward run:
Purſue that nobleneſſe, and chaſte deſire
You ever had, burne in that holy fire;
And a white Martyr to faire memorie
Give up your name, unſoil'd of infamy.

sp.l: How's this? Read yours out ſiſter: this amazes me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Feare not thou yet unblaſted Violet,
Nor let my wanton words a doubt beget,
Live in that peace and ſweetneſſr of thy bud,
Remember whoſe thou art, and grow ſtill good.
Remember what thou art, and ſtand a ſtorie
Fit for thy noble Sex, and thine owne glorie.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I know not what to thinke.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Sure a good woman,
An excellent woman, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It confounds me;
Let 'em uſe all their arts, if theſe be their ends,
The Court I ſay breeds the beſt foes and friends.
Come, let's be honeſt wench, and doe our beſt ſervice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A moſt excellent woman, I will love her. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Olimpia with a Casket, and Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: MAdam, the Duke has ſent for the two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I prethee go: I know thy thoughts are with him.
Go, go Alinda, do not mock me more.
I have found thy heart wench, doe not wrong thy Miſtris,
Thy too much loving Miſtris: doe not abuſe her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your owne faire hands I underſtand ye not.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: By thy own faire eyes I underſtand thee too much,
Too farre, and built a faith there thou haſt ruine.
Goe, and enjoy thy wiſh, thy youth, thy pleaſure,
Enjoy the greatneſſe no doubt he has promiſed,
Enjoy the ſervice of all eyes that ſee thee,
The glory thou haſt aim'd at, and the triumph:
Onely this laſt love I aske, forget thy Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Oh, who has wrong'd me? who has ruin'd me?
Poore wretched Girle, what poyſon is ſlung on thee?
Excellent vertue, from whence flowes this anger?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Go, ask my Brother, ask the faith thou gav'ſt me,
Aske all my favours to thee, aske my love,
Laſt, thy forgetfulneſſe of good: then flye me,
For we muſt part Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are wearie of me;
I muſt confeſſe, I was never worth your ſervice,
Your bounteous favours leſſe; but that my duty,
My ready will, and all I had to ſerve ye—
O heaven thou know'ſt my honeſtie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: No more:
Take heed, heaven has a juſtice: take this ring with yee,
This doting ſpell you gave mee: too well Alinda,
Thou knew'ſt the vertue in't; too well I feele it:
Nay keep that too, it may ſometimes remember ye,
When you are willing to forget who gave it,
And to what vertuous end.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Muſt I goe from yee?
Of all the ſorrowes ſorrow has—muſt I part with yee?
Part with my noble Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Or I with thee wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And part ſtain'd with opinion? Farewell Lady,
Happy and bleſſed Lady, goodneſſe keep yee:
Thus your poore ſervant full of griefe turnes from yee,
For ever full of griefe, for ever from yee.
I have no being now, no friends, no Countrey,
I wander heaven knowes whither, heaven knows how.
No life, now you are loſt: onely mine innocence,
That little left me of my ſelfe, goes with me,
That's all my bread and comfort. I confeſſe Madam,
Truely confeſſe, the Duke has often courted me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And powr'd his ſoule into thee, won thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Doe you think ſo?
Well, time that told this tale, will tell my truth too,
And ſay ye had a faithfull, honeſt ſervant:
The buſineſſe of my life is now to pray for ye,
Pray for your vertuous loves; Pray for your children,
When heaven ſhall make ye happy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How ſhe wounds me?
Either I am undone, or ſhe muſt go: take theſe with yee,
Some toyes may doe ye ſervice; and this money;
And when ye want, I love ye not ſo poorely,
Not yet Alinda, that I would ſee ye periſh.
Prethee be good, and let me heare: look on me,
I love thoſe eyes yet dearely; I have kiſs'd thee,
And now Ile doe't againe: farewell Alinda,
I am too full to ſpeak more, and too wretched. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have my faith,
And all the world my fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would faine heare
What becomes of theſe two Wenches:
And if I can, I will doe 'em good. Enter Gentleman paſsing over the Stage.
Doe you heare my honeſt friend?
He knowes no ſuch name:
What a world of buſineſſe,
Which by interpretation are meere nothings,
Theſe things have here? 'Maſſe now I think on't better,
I wiſh he be not ſent for one of them
To ſome of theſe by-lodgings: me thought I ſaw
A kinde of reference in his face to Bawderie.
sp.stage: Enter Gent. with a Gentlewom. paſsing over the Stage.
sp.l: He has her, but 'tis none of them: hold faſt theefe:
An excellent touzing knave. Miſtris
You are to ſuffer your penance ſome half hour hence now
How farre a fine Court Cuſtard with Plumbs it
Will prevaile with one of theſe waiting gentlewomen,
They are taken with theſe ſoluble things exceedingly;
This is ſome yeoman oth' bottles now that has ſent for hir,
That ſhe calls father: now woe to this Ale incence.
By your leave ſir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Well ſir; what's your pleaſure with me?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You do not know the way to the maids lodgings?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes indeed doe I ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But you will not tell me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No indeed will not I, becauſe you doubt it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Theſe are fine gim-cracks: hey, here comes another,
A Haggon full of wine in's hand, I take it.
Well met my friend, is that wine?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Yes indeed is it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Faith Ile drink on't then.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Ye may, becauſe ye have ſworne ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis very good, Ile drinke a great deale now ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: I cannot helpe it ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ile drinke more yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis in your owne hands.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: There's your pot, I thank ye.
Pray let me drinke againe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Faith but ye ſhall not.
Now have I ſworn I take it. Fare ye well ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: This is the fin'ſt place to live in I e're enterd. Enter Lady.
Here comes a gentle woman, & alone; Ile to her.
Madam, My Lord my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Who's your Lord ſir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The Lord Boroskie, Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray excuſe me:
Here's ſomething for your paines: within this houre ſir,
One of the choiſe young Ladies ſhall attend him:
Pray let it be in that Chamber juts out to the water;
'Tis private and convenient: doe my humble ſervice
To my honourable good Lord, I beſeech ye ſir;
If it pleaſe you to viſit a poore Lady—
You carrie the 'haviour of a noble Gentleman,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhall be bold.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis a good aptneſſe in ye.
I lye here in the Wood-yard, the blew lodgings ſir;
They call me merily the Lady of the—Sir;
A little I know what belongs to a gentleman,
And if it pleaſe you take the paines. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Deare Lady, take the paines?
Why a horſe would not take the pains that thou requir'ſt now,
To cleave old crab-tree? one of the choiſe yong Ladies:
I would I had let this Bawd goe, ſhe has frighted me;
I am cruelly afraid of one of my Tribe now;
But if they will doe, the devill cannot ſtop 'em.
Why ſhould he have a young Lady? are women now
Oth' nature of Bottles, to be ſtopt with Corks?
O the thouſand little furies that flye here now?
How now Captaine? Enter Putskie.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: I come to ſeek you out ſir,
And all the Town I have travell'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's the newes man?

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: That that concernes us all, and very neerely:
The Duke this night holds a great feaſt at Court,
To which he bids for gueſts all his old Counſellors,
And all his favourites: your Father's ſent for.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why he is neither in councell, nor in favour.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Thats it: have an eye now, or never, & a quick one,
An eye that muſt not wink from good intelligence.
I heard a Bird ſing, they mean him no good office.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Art ſure he ſups here? Enter Ancient.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Sure as 'tis day.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis like then:
How now, where haſt thou been Ancient?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Meaſuring the City:
I have left my Brooms at gate here;
By this time the Porter has ſtole 'em to ſweep out raſcals.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Brooms?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I have been crying Brooms all the towne over,
And ſuch a Mart I have made, there's no trade neare it.
O the young handſome wenches, how they twitter'd,
When they but ſaw me ſhake my ware, and ſing too;
Come hither Maſter Broom-man I beſeech ye:
Good Maſter Broom-man hither cries another.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou art a mad fellow.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: They are all as mad as I: they all have trades now,
And roare about the ſtreets like Bull-beggers.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What company of ſouldiers are they?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: By this meanes I have gather'd
Above a thouſand tall and hardy ſouldiers,
If need be Colonell.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That need's come Ancient,
And 'twas diſcreetly done: goe, draw 'em preſently,
But without ſuſpition: this night we ſhall need 'em;
Let 'em be neare the Court, let Putskie guide 'em;
And wait me for occaſion: here Ile ſtay ſtill.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: If it fall out we are ready; if not we are ſcatter'd:
Ile wait ye at an inch.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Doe, farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are the Souldiers ſtill ſo mutinous?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More then ever,
No Law nor Juſtice frights 'em: all the Towne over
They play new pranks and gambols: no mans perſon,
Of what degree ſoever, free from abuſes:
And durſt they doe this, (let your grace conſider)
Theſe monſtrous, moſt offenſive things, theſe villanies,
If not ſet on, and fed? if not by one
They honour more then you? and more aw'd by him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Happily their owne wants.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: I offer to ſupply 'em,
And every houre make tender of their moneyes:
They ſcorne it, laugh at me that offer it:
I feare the next device will be my life ſir;
And willingly Ile give it, ſo they ſtay there.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Doe you think Lord Archas privie?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: More then thought,
I know it Sir, I know they durſt not doe
Theſe violent rude things, abuſe the State thus,
But that they have a hope by his ambitions—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more: he's ſent for?

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Yes, and will be here ſure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let me talke further with you anon.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ile wait ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Did you ſpeak to the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They'll attend your grace preſently.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How doe you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My eyes are too dull Judges.
They wait here ſir. Exit. Enter Honora and Viola.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be you gone then: Come in Ladies.
Welcom toth' court ſweet beauties; now the court ſhines,
When ſuch true beames of beauty ſtrike amongſt us:
Welcome, welcome, even as your owne joyes welcome.
How doe you like the Court? how ſeems it to you?
Is't not a place created for all ſweetneſſe?
Why were you made ſuch ſtrangers to this happineſſe?
Barr'd the delights this holds? the richeſt jewels
Set ne're ſo well, if then not worne to wonder,
By judging eyes not ſet off, loſe their luſtre:
Your Countrey ſhades are faint; blaſters of beauty;
The manners like the place, obſcure and heavie;
The Roſe buds of your beauties turne to cankers,
Eaten with inward thoughts: whilſt there ye wander.
Here Ladies, here, you were not made for Cloiſters,
Here is the Sphere you move in: here ſhine nobly,
And by your powerfull influence command all:
What a ſweet modeſtie dwells round about 'em,
And like a nipping morne pulls in their bloſſoms?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your grace ſpeaks cunningly, you doe not this,
I hope ſir, to betray us, wee are poore triumphs;
Nor can our loſſe of honour adde to you ſir:
Great men, and great thoughts, ſeek things great & worthy,
Subjects to make 'em live, and not to loſe 'em;
Conqueſts ſo nobly won, can never periſh;
We are two ſimple maids, untutor'd here ſir;
Two honeſt maids, is that a ſin at Court ſir?
Our breeding is obedience, but to good things,
To vertuous and to faire: what wou'd you win on us?
Why doe I aske that queſtion, when I have found yee?
Your Preamble has pow'rd your heart out to us;
You would diſhonour us; which in your tranſlation
Here at the Court reads thus, your grace would love us,
Moſt dearely love us: ſticke us up for miſtreſſes:
Moſt cerraine, there are thouſands of our Sex ſir
That would be glad of this, and handſome women,
And crowd into this favour, faire young women,
Excellent beauties ſir: when ye have enjoyd 'em,
And ſuckt thoſe ſweets they have, what Saints are theſe then?
What worſhip have they won? what name you gheſſe ſir,
What ſtorie added to their time, a ſweet one?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A brave ſpirited wench.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Ile tell your grace,
And tell yee true: ye are deceiv'd in us two,
Extreamly cozend ſir: And yet in my eye
You are the handſomſt man I evet lookt on,
The goodlieſt gentleman; take that hope with yee;
And were I fit to be your wife (ſo much I honour yee)
Truſt me I would ſcratch for ye but I would have yee.
I would wooe you then.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She amazes me:
But how am I deceiv'd?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O we are too honeſt,
Believe it ſir, too honeſt, far too honeſt,
The way that you propound too ignorant,
And there is no medling with us; for we are fooles too,
Obſtinate, peeviſh fooles: if I would be ill,
And had a wantons itch, to kick my heeles up,
I would not leap into th'Sun, and doe't there,
That all the world might ſee me: an obſcure ſhade ſir,
Darke as the deed, there is no truſting light with it,
Nor thats that lighter far, vain-glorious greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You will love me as your friend?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I will honour yee,
As your poore humble handmaid ſerve, and pray for ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What ſayes my little one; you are not to obſtinate?
Lord how the bluſhes: here are truely faire ſoules:
Come you will be my love?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good ſir be good to me,
Indeed Ile doe the beſt I can to pleaſe yee;
I doe beſeech your grace: Alas I feare ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What ſhouldſt thou feare?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Fie ſir, this is not noble.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why doe I ſtand entreating, where my power—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You have no power, at leaſt you ought to have none
In bad and beaſtly things: arm'd thus, Ile dye here,
Before ſhe ſuffer wrong.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Another Archas?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: His childe ſir, and his ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ile deale with you then,
For here's the honour to be won: ſit down ſweet,
Prethee Honora ſit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Now ye intreat I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I doe, and will deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That's too much kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prethee look on me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yes: I love to ſee yee,
And could look on an age thus, and admire ye:
Whilſt ye are good and temperate I dare touch ye,
Kiſſe your white hand.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why not my lips?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I dare ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I doe not thinke ye dare.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am no coward.
Doe you believe me now? or now? or now ſir?
You make me bluſh: but ſure I mean no ill ſir:
It had been fitter you had kiſs'd me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That Ile doe too.
What haſt thou wrought into me?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hope all goodneſſe:
Whilſt ye are thus, thus honeſt, I dare doe any thing,
Thus hang about your neck, and thus doat on yee;
Bleſſe thoſe faire lights: hell take me if I durſt not—
But good Sir pardon me. Siſter come hither,
Come hither, feare not wench: come hither, bluſh not,
Come kiſſe the Prince, the vertuous Prince, the good Prince:
Certaine he is excellent honeſt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sit downe, and hug him ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Fie Honora,
Wanton Honora; is this the modeſty,
The noble chaſtity your on-ſet ſhew'd me,
At firſt charge beaten back? Away.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank ye:
Upon my knees I pray, heaven too may thank ye;
Ye have deceiv'd me cunningly, yet nobly
Ye have cozen'd me: In all your hopefull life yet,
A Scene of greater honour, you ne're acted:
I knew Fame was a lyar, too long, and loud tongu'd,
And now I have found it: O my vertuous Maſter.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My vertuous Maſter too.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Now you are thus,
What ſhall become of me let Fortune caſt for't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ile be that fortune, if I live Honora, Enter Alin.
Thou haſt done a cure upon me, counſell could not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here take your ring ſir, & whom ye mean to ruine,
Give it to her next; I have paid for't dearely.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A Ring to her?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why frownes my faire Alinda?
I have forgot both theſe againe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Stand ſtill ſir,
Ye have that violent killing fire upon ye,
Conſumes all honour, credit, faith.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My Royall Miſtris favour towards me,
Woe-worth ye ſir, ye have poyſon'd, blaſted.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I ſweet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have taken that unmanly liberty,
Which in a worſe man, is vaine-glorious feigning,
And kild my truth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Upon my life 'tis falſe wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ladies,
Take heed, ye have a cunning gamſter,
A handſome, and a high; come ſtoar'd with Antidotes,
He has infections elſe will fire your blouds.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prethee Alinda heare me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Words ſteept in honey,
That will ſo melt into your mindes, buy Chaſtity,
A thouſand wayes, a thouſand knots to tie ye;
And when he has bound ye his, a thouſand ruines.
A poore loſt woman ye have made me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ile maintaine thee,
And nobly too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That Gin's too weak to take me:
Take heed, take heed young Ladies: ſtill take heed,
Take heed of promiſes, take heed of gifts,
Of forced feigned ſorrowes, ſighes, take heed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By all that's mine, Alinda—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sweare
By your miſchiefes:
O whither ſhall I goe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Goe back againe,
Ile force her take thee, love thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Fare ye well Sir,
I will not curſe ye; onely this dwell with ye,
When ever you love, a falſe beliefe light on ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Wee'll take our leaves too ſir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Part all the world now,
Since ſhe is gone.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You are crooked yet, deare Maſter,
And ſtill I feare— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am vext,
And ſome ſhall finde it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange
To me to ſee the Court, and welcome:
O royall place, how have I lov'd and ſerv'd thee?
Who lies on this ſide, know'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Lord Burris.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou haſt nam'd a gentleman
I ſtand much bound to.
I think he ſent the Casket ſir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: An honeſt minded man, a noble Courtier:
The Duke made perfect choice when he took him.
Goe you home, I ſhall hit the way
Without a guide now.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You may want ſomething ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Onely my horſes,
Which after Supper let the Groom wait with:
Ile have no more attendance here.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your will ſir? Exit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: You are well met here ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How now boy,
How do'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhould aske
You that queſtion: how doe you ſir?
How doe you feele your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why well, and luſtie.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What doe you here then?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why I am ſent for
To Supper with the Duke.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Have you no meat at home?
Or doe you long to feed as hunted Deere doe,
In doubt and feare?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have an excellent ſtomach,
And can I uſe it better
Then among my friends boy?
How doe the wenches?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They doe well enough ſir,
They know the worſt by this time: pray be rul'd ſir,
Goe home againe, and if ye have a Supper
Eate it in quiet there: this is no place for ye,
Eſpecially at this time,
Take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: May be they'll drink hard;
I could have drunk my ſhare Boy.
Though I am old, I will not out.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I hope you will.
Hark in your eare: the Court's
Too quick of hearing.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not mean me wel?
Thou art abus'd and cozen'd.
Away, away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To that end ſir I tell ye.
Away, if ye love your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Who dare doe theſe things,
That ever heard of honeſty?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Old Gntleman,
Take a fooles counſell.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis a fooles indeed;
A very fooles: thou haſt more of
Theſe flams in thee, theſe muſty doubts:
Is't fit the Duke ſend for me,
And honour me to eate within his preſence,
And I, like a tal fellow, play at bo-peep
With his pleaſure?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Take heed
Of bo-peep with your pate, your pate ſir,
I ſpeak plain language now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If 'twere not here,
Where reverence bids-me hold,
I would ſo ſwinge thee, thou rude,
Unmanner'd knave; take from his bounty,
His honour that he gives me, to beget
Sawcy, and ſullen feares?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are not mad ſure:
By this faire light, I ſpeak
But what is whiſper'd,
And whiſper'd for a truth.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A dog: drunken people,
That in their Pot ſee viſions,
And turne ſtates, mad-men and children:
Prethee doe not follow me;
I tell thee I am angrie:
Doe not follow me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am as angrie
As you for your heart.
I and as wilfull too: goe, like a Wood-cock,
And thruſt your neck ith' nooſe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ile kill thee.
And thou ſpeakſt but three words more.
Doe not follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A ſtrange old fooliſh fellow: I ſhall heare yet,
And if I doe not my part hiſſe at me. Exit.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter two Servants preparing a Banquet.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Beleeve me fellow here will be luſty drinking.
Many a waſht pate in wine I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: I am glad the old Generall's come: upon my conſcience
That joy will make half the Court drunk. Hark the Trumpets,
They are comming on; away.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Wee'll have a rowſe too. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Archas, Burris, Boroskie, Attend. Gent,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Come ſeat your ſelves: Lord Archas ſit you there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis farre above my worth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ile have it ſo:
Are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: All the Guards are ſet,
The Coutt gates ſhut.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then doe as I preſcrib'd yee.
Be ſure no further.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ſhall well obſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come bring ſome wine: here's to my ſiſter gentlemen;
A health, and mirth to all.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pray fill it full ſir.
'Tis a high health to vertue: here Lord Burris,
A maiden health: you are moſt fit to pledge it,
You have a maiden ſoule, and much I honour it.
Paſſion o'me, ye are ſad man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How now Burris.
Goe to, no more of this.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take the rowſe freely,
'Twill warme your bloud, and make ye fit for jollity.
Your graces pardon: when we get a cup ſir,
We old men prate a pace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Mirth makes a banque●;
As you love me no more.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I thank your grace.
Give me it; Lord Boroskie.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: I have ill braines ſir.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Damnable ill, I know it.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: But Ile pledge ſir
This vertuous health. Enter two Servants with Cloaks.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: The more unfit for thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, bring out Robes, & let my gueſts look nobly,
Fit for my love, and preſence: begin downward.
Off with your cloaks, take new.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your grace deales truely
Like a munificent Prince, with your poor ſubjects,
Who would not fight for you? what cold dull coward
Durſt ſeek to ſave his life when you would aske it?
Begin a new health in your new adornments,
The Dukes, the Royall Dukes: ha, what have I got
Sir? ha! the robe of death!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You have deſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The livorie of the grave? do you ſtart all from me?
Doe I ſmell of earth already? Sir look on me,
And like a man; is this your entertainment?
Doe you bid your worthieſt gueſts to bloudy Banquets.
A Guard upon me too? this is too foule play
Boy to thy good, thine honour; thou wretched Ruler,
Thou ſonne of fooles and flatterers, heire of hypocrites,
Am I ſerv'd in a hearſe that ſav'd ye all?
Are ye men or devills? doe ye gape upon me,
Wider, and ſwallow all my ſervices?
Entombe them firſt, my faith next, then my integritie,
And let theſe ſtruggle with your mangy mindes,
Your ſear'd, and ſeal'd up conſciences, till ye burſt.

sp.speaker: Boroſ.
sp.l: Theſe words are death.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No thoſe deeds that want rewards, ſirrah,
Thoſe Battells I have fought, thoſe horrid dangers,
Leaner then death, and wilder then deſtruction,
I have march'd upon, theſe honour'd wounds, times ſtory,
The bloud I have loſt, the youth, the ſorrowes ſuffer'd,
Theſe are my death, theſe that can ne're be recompenced,
Theſe that ye ſit a brooding on like Toads,
Sucking from my deſerts the ſweets and favours,
And render me no pay againe but poiſons.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The proud vaine ſouldier thou haſt ſet—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt.
Now by my little time of life lyeſt baſely,
Malitiouſly and loudly: how I ſcorne thee?
If I had ſweld the ſouldier, or intended
As act in perſon, leaning to diſhonour,
As ye would faine have forced me, witneſſe heaven,
Where cleareſt underſtanding of all truth is,
(For theſe are ſpightfull men, and know no piety)
When Olin came, grim Olin, when his marches,
His laſt Incurſions made the City ſweat,
And drove before him, as a ſtorme drives Haile,
Such ſhowrs of froſted fears, ſhook all your heart-ſtrings;
Then when the Volga trembled at his terrour,
And hid his ſeven curl'd heads, afraid of bruiſing,
By his arm'd horſes hoofes; had I been falſe then,
Or blowne a treacherous fire into the ſouldier,
Had but one ſparke of villanie liv'd within me,
Ye'ad had ſome ſhadow for this black about me.
Where was your ſouldierſhip? why went not you out?
And all your right honourable valour with ye?
Why met ye not the Tartar, and defi'd him?
Drew your dead-doing ſword, and buckl'd with him?
Shot through his Squadrons like a fierie Meteor?
And as we ſee a dreadfull clap of thunder
Rend the ſtiffe hearted Oakes, and toſſe their roots up:
Why did not you ſo charge him? you were ſick then,
You that dare taint my credit ſlipt to bed then,
Stewing and fainting with the feares ye had,
A whorſon ſhaking fit oppreſt your Lordſhip:
Bluſh Coward knave, and all the world hiſſe at thee.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Exceed not my command. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Are you gone too? Come weep not honeſt Burris,
Good loving Lord, no more teares: 'Tis not his malice,
This fellowes malice, nor the Dukes diſpleaſure,
By bold bad men, crowded into his nature,
Can ſtartle me: fortune ne're raz'd this Fort yet:
I am the ſame, the ſame man, living, dying;
The ſame mind to 'em both, I poize thus equall;
Onely the jugling way that told me to it,
The Judas way, to kiſſe me, bid me welcome,
And cut my throat, a little ſticks upon me.
Farewell, commend me to his grace, and tell him,
The world is full of ſervants, he may have many:
And ſome I wiſh him honeſt: hee's undone elſe:
But ſuch another doating Archas never,
So try'd and touch'd a faith: farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Be ſtrong my Lord: you muſt not go thus lightly.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now, what's to doe? what ſayes the Law unto me?
Give me my great offence that ſpeaks me guilty,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Laying aſide a thouſand petty matters,
As ſcornes, and inſolencies both from your ſelfe and followers,
Which you put firſt fire to, and theſe are deadly,
I come to one maine cauſe, which though it carries
A ſtrangeneſſe in the circumſtance, it carries death too,
Not to be pardon'd neither: ye have done a ſacriledge.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: High heaven defend me man: how, how Borosky?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Ye have tooke from the Temple thoſe vow'd Arms,
The holy Ornament you hung up there,
No abſolution of your vow, no order
From holy Church to give 'em backe unto you
After they were purified from war, and reſted
From bloud, made cleane by ceremony: from the Altar
You ſnatch'd 'em up againe, againe ye wore 'em,
Againe you ſtaind 'em, ſtaind your vow, the Church too,
And rob'd it of that right was none of yours ſir,
For which the Law requires your head, ye know it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thoſe Armes I fought in laſt?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: God a mercy,
Thou haſt hunted out a notable cauſe to kill me:
A ſubtle one: I dye, for ſaving all you;
Good ſir remember if you can, the neceſſitie,
The ſuddaineſſe of time, the State all ſtood in;
I was entreated to, kneel'd to, and prai'd to,
The Duke himſelfe, the Princes, all the Nobles,
The cries of Infants, bedrid fathers, virgins;
Prethee find out a better cauſe, a hanſomer,
This will undo thee too; people will ſpit at thee,
The devill himſelfe would be aſham'd of this cauſe;
Becauſe my haſt made me forget the ceremony,
The preſent danger every where, muſt my life ſatisfie?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It muſt, and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O baſe ungratefull people,
Have ye no other Sword to cut my throat with
But mine owne nobleneſſe? I confeſſe, I tooke 'em,
The vow not yet abſolv'd, I hung 'em up with:
Wore 'em, fought in 'em, gilded 'em againe
In the fierce Tartars blouds; for you I tooke 'em,
For your peculiar ſafety, Lord, for all,
I wore 'em for my Countries health, that gron'd then:
Tooke from the Temple, to preſerve the Temple;
That holy place, and all the ſacred monuments,
The reverent ſhrines of Saints, ador'd and honour'd,
Had been conſum'd to aſhes, their owne ſacrifice,
Had I been ſlacke, or ſtaid that abſolution.
No Prieſt had liv'd to give it; my owne honour
Cure of my Country murder me?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: No, no ſir,
I ſhall force that from ye, will make this cauſe light too,
Away with him: I ſhall plucke downe that heart ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Breake it thou maieſt; but if it bend, for pitty,
Doggs, and Kits eate it: come I am honours Martyr. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 6.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Exceed my warrant?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know he loves him not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He dares as well meet death, as do it, eat wildfire,
Through a few feares I meane to trye his goodneſſe,
That I may find him fit, to weare here Burris;
I know Boroſkie hates him, to death hates him,
I know he's a Serpent too, a ſwolne one Noiſe within.
But I have puld his ſting out; what noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Within. Down with 'em, down with 'em, down with the gates.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.p: Within. Stand, ſtand, ſtand.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.p: Within. Fire the Pallace before ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Upon my life the Souldier, ſir, the Souldier,
A miſerable time is come. Enter Gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Oh ſave him,
Upon my knees, my hearts knees, ſave Lord Archas,
We are undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Dares he touch his body?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He racks him fearefully, moſt fearefully.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Away Burris,
Take men, and take him from him; clap him up,
And if I live, I'le find a ſtrange death for him: Ex. Bur.
Are the Souldiers broke in?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By this time ſure they are ſir,
They beate the gates extreamely, beate the people.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Get me a guard about me; make ſure the lodgings
And ſpeake the Souldiers faire.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray heaven that take ſir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Putsky, Ancient, Souldiers, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Put,
sp.l: Give us the Generall, wee'l fire the Court elſe,
Render him ſafe and well,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do not fire the Cellar,
There's excellent wine in't Captain, and though it be cold whether,
I do not love it mul'd; bring out the Generall,
Wee'll light ye, ſuch a bonefire elſe; where are ye?
Speak, or wee'l toſſe your Turrets, peep out of your hives
Wee'l ſmoake ye elſe: is not that a noſe there?
Put out that note againe, and if thou dar'ſt
But blow it before us: now he creepes out on's but rough.

sp.speaker: Putſ.
sp.l: Give us the Generall. Enter Gent.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, Gentlemen;
Or any thing ye can deſire.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: You musk-cat
Cordevan-skin, we will not take your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Where is the Duke? ſpeak ſuddenly, and ſend him hether.

sp.speaker: Anc
sp.l: Or wee'l ſo frie your buttucks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good ſweet Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We are neither good, nor ſweet, we are Souldiers
And you miſcreants that abuſe the Generall,
Give fire my boyes 'tis a darke evening,
Let's light 'em to their lodgings.

div.stage: Enter Olimpia, Honora, Viola, Theodore, Women.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good brother be not fierce.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I will not hurt her,
Feare not ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'May do what you pleaſe ſit,
I have a ſorrow that exceeds all yours,
And more, contemnes all danger. Enter Duke above

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He's here; what would ye Souldiers? wherefore troop ye
Like mutinous mad-men thus?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Give me my father.

sp.speaker: Put. Anc.
sp.l: Give us our Generall.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Set him here before us,
Ye ſee the pledge we have got; ye ſee theſe torches;
All ſhall to aſhes, as I live, immediately,
A thouſand lives for one.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But heare me?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, we come not to diſpute. Enter Archas and Bur.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: By heaven I ſweare he's rackt and whipt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh my poore father!

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Burne, kill, and burne.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold, hold I ſay: hold Souldiers,
On your allegeance hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We muſt not.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold:
I ſweare by heaven he it a barbarous Traitour ſtirs firſt,
A villaine, and a ſtranger to obedience,
Never my Souldier more, nor friend to honour:
Why did you uſe your old man thus? thus cruelly
Torture his poore weake body? I ever lov'd ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forget me in theſe wrongs, moſt noble Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have balme enough for all my hurts: weep no more ſir,
A ſatisfaction for a thouſand ſorrowes:
I do beleeve ye innocent, a good man,
And heaven forgive that naughty thing that wrong'd me.
Why looke ye wild my friends? why ſtare ye one me?
I charge ye as ye are men, my men, my lovers,
As ye are honeſt faithfull men, faire Souldiers,
Let downe your anger: Is not this our Soveraigne,
The head of mercie, and of Law? who dares then,
But Rebels ſcorning Law, appeare thus violent?
Is this a place for Swords? for threatning fires?
The reverence of this houſe dares any touch,
But with obedient knees, and pious duties?
Are we not all his Subjects? all ſworn to him?
Has not he power to puniſh our offences?
And do not we dayly fall into 'em? aſſure your ſelves
I did offend and highly, grievouſly,
This good ſweet Prince I offended, my life forfeited,
Which yet his mercy, and his old love met with,
And only let me feele his light rod this way:
Ye are to thanke him for your Generall,
Pray for his life, and fortune: ſweat your blouds for him.
You are offenders too, daily offenders,
Proud inſolencies dwell in your hearts, and ye do 'em,
Do 'em againſt his peace, his Law, his Perſon;
Ye ſee he only ſorrowes for your ſins,
And where his power might perſecute, forgives ye:
For ſhame put up your Swords, for honeſty,
For orders ſake and whoſe ye are, my Souldiers,
Be not ſo rude.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They have drawne bloud from ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That was the bloud rebel'd, the naughty bloud,
The proud provoking bloud; 'tis well 'tis out boy;
Give you example firſt; draw out, and orderly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Good brother doe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Honeſt and high example,
As thou wilt haue my bleſſing follow thee,
Inherit all mine honours: thanke ye Theodore,
My worthy ſon.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If harme come, thanke your ſelfe ſir;
I muſt obey ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Captaine, you know the way now:
A good man, and a valiant, you were ever,
Inclind to honeſt things: I thanke ye Captaine. Ex. Soul.
Souldiers, I thanke ye all: and love me ſtill,
But do not love me ſo you loſe allegeance,
Love that above your lives: once more I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring him to reſt, and let our cares waite on him;
Thou excellent old man, thou top of honour,
Where juſtice, and obedience onlie build,
Thou ſtocke of vertue, how am I bound to love thee?
In all thy noble waies to follow thee?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Remember him that vext him ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Remember?
When I forget that villaine, and to pay him
For all his miſchiefes, may all good thoughts forget me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am very ſore,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring him to bed with eaſe Gentlemen,
For everie ſtripe I'le drop a teare to waſh 'em,
And in my ſad repentance—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
I have a life yet left to gaine that love ſir. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: HOw do's Lord Archas yet?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But weake and't pleaſe ye,
Yet all the helpes that art can, are applied to him;
His heart's untouch't, and whole yet; and no doubt ſir,
His minde being found, his body ſoone will follow.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O that baſe knave that wrong'd him, without leave too;
But I ſhall find an houre to give him thankes for't;
He's faſt I hope?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As faſt as irons can keep him:
But the moſt fearefull wretch—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He has a conſcience,
A cruell ſtinging one I warrant him,
A loaden one: But what newes of the Souldier?
I did not like their parting, 'twas too ſullen.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That they keep ſtill, and I feare a worſe clap:
They are drawn out of the Towne, and ſtand in counſels,
Hatching unquiet thoughts, and cruell purpoſes:
I went my ſelfe unto 'em, talk't with the Captaines,
Whom I found fraught with nothing but loud murmurs,
And deſperate curſes, ſounding theſe words often
Like trumpets to their angers: we are ruin'd,
Our ſervices turn'd to diſgraces, miſchiefes,
Our brave old Generall, like one had pilfer'd,
Tortur'd, and whipt: the Collonells eyes like torches,
Blaze everie where and fright faire peace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yet worſe ſir:
The newes is currant now, they meane to leave ye,
Leave their allegiance: and under Olins charge
The bloudy Enemy march ſtrait againſt ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I have heard this too ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This muſt be prevented,
And ſuddenly, and warily.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: 'Tis time ſir,
But what to miniſter, or how?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Go in with me,
And there wee'l thinke upon't: ſuch blows as theſe,
Equall defences aske, elſe they diſpleaſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Lord, what a coile has here been with theſe Souldiers?
They are cruell fellowes.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: And yet me thought we found 'em
Hanſome enough; I'le tell thee true Peteſca,
I look'd for other manner of dealings from 'em,
And had prepar'd my ſelfe; but where's my Lady?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: In her old dumps within: monſtrous mellancholly;
Sure ſhe was mad of this wench.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: And ſhe had been a man,
She would have been a great deale madder, I am glad ſhe is ſhifted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas a wicked thing for me to betray her, Ent. Alinda
And yet I muſt confeſſe ſhe ſtood in our lights,
What young thing's this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Good morrow beuteous Gentlewomen:
Pray you is the Princeſſe ſtirring yet?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: He has her face.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Her very tongue, and tone too: her youth upon him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I gheſſe ye to be the Princeſſe women.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes, We are ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pray is there not a Gentlewoman waiting on her Grace,
Ye cal Alinda?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The devill ſure in her ſhape.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I have heard her tell my Lady of a brother,
An only brother that ſhe had: in travell—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Mas, I remember that: this may be he too:
I would this thing would ſerve her. Enter Olimpia

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: So would I wench,
We ſhould love him better ſure: ſir, here's the Princes,
She beſt can ſatisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How I love that preſence!
O bleſſed eyes how nobly ſhines your comforts!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: We know not Madam:
He ask'd us for your Grace: and as we gueſſe it,
He is Al ndas Brother.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ha? let me marke him:
My griefe has almoſt blinded me: her brother?
By Venus, he has all her ſweetneſſe upon him:
Two ſilver drops of dew, were never liker.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Gratious Lady—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That pleaſant pipe he has too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Being my happineſſe to paſſe by this way,
And having as I underſtand by Letters,
A ſiſter in your vertuous ſervice Madam—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O now my heart, my heart akes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All the comfort
My poore youth has, all that my hopes have built me,
I thought it my firſt duty, my beſt ſervice
Here to arive firſt, humbly to thanke your Grace
For my poore firſt, humbly to thanke your nobleneſſe,
That bounteous goodneſſe in ye.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis he certainly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That ſpring of favour to her; with my life Madam
If any ſuch moſt happy meanes might meet me,
To ſhew my thankefulneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What have I done foole?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She came a ſtranger to your Grace, no Courtier;
Nor of that curious breed beſits your ſervice,
Yet one I dare aſſure my ſoule, that lov'd ye
Before ſhe ſaw ye; doated on your vertues;
Before ſhe knew thoſe faire eyes long'd to read 'em,
You only had her prayers, you her wiſhes;
And that one hope to be yours once, preſerv'd her,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have done wickedly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little beauty,
Such as a Cottage breeds, ſhe brought along with her;
And yet our Countrie eyes eſteem'd it much too:
But for her beauteous mind forget great Lady
I am her brother, and let me ſpeake a ſtranger,
Since ſhe was able to beget a thought, 'twas honeſt,
The dayly ſtuddy how to fit your ſervices,
Truly to tread that vertuous path you walke in,
So fir'd her honeſt ſoule, we thought her Sainted;
I preſume ſhe is ſtill the ſame: I would faine ſee her,
For Madam, 'tis no little love I owe her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sir, ſuch a maid there was, I had—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: There was Madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O my poore wench: eyes, I will ever curſe ye
For your credulity. Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's her name, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Give me a little leave ſir to lament her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is ſhe dead Lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dead ſir, to my ſervice.
She is gone, pray ye aske no further,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I obey Madam:
Gone? now muſt I lament too: ſaid ye gone, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Gone, gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That's a cruell ſaying:
Her honour too?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Prethee looke angry on me,
And if thou ever lovedſt her, ſpit upon me;
Doe ſomething like a brother, like a friend,
And do not only ſay thou lov'ſt her—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ye amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I ruin'd her, I wrong'd her, I abus'd her;
Poore innocent ſoule, I flung her; ſweet Alinda,
Thou vertuous maid, my ſoule now cals thee vertuous.
Why do ye not raile now at me?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: For what Lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Call me baſe treacherous woman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Raſhly I thought her falſe, and put her from me,
Raſhly, and madly I betrai'd her modeſty,
Put her to wande, heaven knows where: nay, more ſir,
Stucke a blacke brand upon her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Twas not well Lady,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Twas damnable: ſhe loving me ſo deerely,
Never poore wench lov'd ſo: Sir, beleeve me,
'Twas the moſt dutious wench, the beſt companion,
When I was pleas'd, the happieſt, and the gladdeſt,
The modeſteſt ſweet nature dwelt within her:
I ſaw all this, I knew all this. I lov'd it,
I doated on it too, and yet I kil'd it:
O what have I forſaken? what have I loſt?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, I'le take my leave, ſince ſhe is wandring,
'Tis fit I know no reſt.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Will you go too ſir?
I have not wrong'd you yet, if you dare truſt me,
For yet I love Alinda there, I honour her,
I love to looke upon thoſe eyes that ſpeake her,
To read that face againe, modeſty keepe me,
Alinda, in that ſhape: but why ſhould you truſt me,
'Twas I betray'd your ſiſter, I undid her;
And beleeve me, gentle youth, 'tis I weep for her:
Appoint what pennance you pleaſe: but ſtay then,
And ſee me performe it; aske what honour this place
Is able to heape on ye, or what wealth:
If following me will like ye, my care of ye,
Which for your ſiſters ſake, for your owne goodneſſe—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not all the honour earth h'as, now ſhe's gone Lady,
Not all the favour; yet if I ſought preferment,
Under your bounteous Grace I would only take it.
Peace reſt upon ye: one ſad teare every day
For poore Alindas ſake, 'tis fit ye pay, Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thouſand noble youth, and when I ſleep,
Even in my ſilver ſlumbers ſtill I'le weep. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Have ye been with 'em?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes, and 't pleaſe your Grace,
But no perſwaſion ſerves 'em, nor no promiſe,
They are fearefull angry, and by this time ſir,
Upon their march to the enemy-

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They muſt be ſtopt. Enter Burris.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I, but what force is able? and what leader—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How now, have you been with Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes, and't pleaſe ye,
And told him all: he frets like a chaſ'd Lyon,
And cals for his Armes: and all thoſe honeſt Courtiers
That dare draw Swords.

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: Is he able to do any thing?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: His mind is well enough; and where his charge is,
Let him be ne're ſo ſore, 'tis a full Army.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who commands the Rebels?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: The young Collonell,
That makes the old man almoſt mad: he ſweares ſir,
He will not ſpare his Sons head for the Dukedome.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is the Court in Armes?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As faſt as they can buſſell,
Every man mad to goe now: inſpir'd ſtrangely,
As if they were to force the Enemie,
I beſeech your Grace to give me leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Pray go ſir,
And looke to the old man well; take up all fairely,
And let no bloud be ſpilt; take generall pardons,
And quench this fury with faire peace.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I ſhall ſir,
Or ſeale it with my ſervice; they are villaines;
The Court is up: good ſir, go ſtrengthen 'em,
Your Royall ſight will make 'em ſcorne all dangers;
The Generall needs no proofe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come let's go view 'em. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Theodore, Putskie, Ancient, Souldiers, Drums, and Collours.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Tis known we are up, and marching: no ſubmiſſion,
No promiſe of baſe peace can cure our maladies,
We have ſuffer'd beyond all repaire of honour:
Your valiant old man's whipt; whipt Gentlemen,
Whipt like a ſlave: that fleſh that never trembled,
Nor ſhrunke one ſinew at a thouſand charges,
That noble body rib'd in armes, the Enemy
So often ſhooke at, and then ſhun'd like thunder,
That bodies torne with laſhes.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Let's turne head.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Turne nothing Gentlemen, let's march on fairely,
Unleſſe they charge us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thinke ſtill of his abuſes,
And keep your angers.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: He was whipt like a top,
I never ſaw a whore ſo lac'd: Court ſchoole-butter?
Is this their diet? I'le dreſſe 'em one running banquet:
What Oracle can alter us? did not we ſee him?
See him we lov'd?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And though we did obey him,
Forc'd by his reverence for that time; is't fit Gentlemen?
My noble friends, is't fit we men, and Souldiers,
Live to endure this, and looke on too?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Forward:
They may call backe the Sun as ſoone, ſtay time,
Preſcribe a Law to death, as we endure this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They will make ye all faire promiſes.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We care not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Uſe all their arts upon ye.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Hang all their arts.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: And happily they'l bring him with 'em.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: March apace then,
He is old and cannot overtake us.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Say he doe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Wee'l run away with him: they ſhall never ſee him more:
The truth is, wee'l heare nothing, ſtop at nothing,
Conſider nothing but our way; beleeve nothing,
Not though they ſay their prayers: be content with nothing,
But the knocking out their braines: and laſt, do nothing
But ban 'em and curſe 'em, till we come to kill 'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Remove then forwards bravely; keep your minds whole,
And the next time we face 'em, ſhall be fatall. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Archas, Duke, Bur. Gent. and Sould.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Peace to your Grace; take reſt ſir, they are before us. Ex. Du.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They are ſir, and upon the ma●ch

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Lord Burris,
Take you thoſe horſe and coaſt 'em: upon the firſt advantage,
If they will not ſlacke their march, charge 'em up roundly,
By that time I'le come in.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I'le do it truly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How do you feele your ſelfe ſir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Well, I thanke ye;
A little weake, but anger ſhall ſupply that;
You will all ſtand bravely to it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whilſt we have lives ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye ſpeake like Gentlemen; I'le make the knaves know,
The proudeſt, and the ſtrongeſt hearted Rebell,
They have a law to live in, and they ſhall have;
Beat up a pace, by this time he is upon 'em, Drum within,
And ſword, but hold me now, thou ſhalt play ever. Ex.
sp.stage: Enter Drums beating, Theodore, Put skie, Ancient, and their Souldiers.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Stand, ſtand, ſtand cloſe, and ſure; Enter Bur. and 1 or 2 Soul.
The horſe will charge us.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Let 'em come one, we have provender ſit for 'em.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here comes Lord Burris ſir, I thinke to parley.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are welcome noble ſir, I hope to our part.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: No, valiant Collonell, I am come to chide ye,
To pitty ye; to kill ye, if theſe faile me;
Fie, what diſhonour ſeeke ye? what blacke infamy!
Why do ye draw out thus? draw all ſhame with ye?
Are theſe ſit cares in ſubjects? I command ye
Lay downe your armes againe, move in that peace,
That faire obedience you were bred in.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Charge us?
We come not here to argue.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Charge up bravely,
And hotly too, we have hot ſpleenes to meet ye, Enter Ar. Gent. & Soul.
Hot as the ſhames are offer'd us.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Looke behind ye.
Do you ſee that old man? do you know him Souldiers?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your father ſir, beleeve me—

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You know his marches,
You have ſeene his executions: is it yet peace?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Wee'l dye here firſt.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Farewell: you'l heare on's preſently.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay Burris: this is too poore, too beggerly a body
To beare the honour of a charge from me,
A ſort of tatterd Rebels; go provide Gallowſes;
Ye are troubled with hot heads, I'le coole ye preſently:
Theſe looke like men that were my Souldiers
Now I behold 'em neerly, and more narrowly,
My honeſt friends: where got they theſe faire figures?
Where did they ſteale theſe ſhapes?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: They are ſtrooke already.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do you ſee that fellow there; that goodly Rebell?
He lookes as like a Captaine, I lov'd tenderly:
A fellow of a faith indeed.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: He has ſham'd him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And that that beares the Collors there, moſt certaine
So like an Ancient of mine owne, a brave fellow,
A loving and obedient, that beleeve me Burris,
I am amaz'd and troubled: and were it not
I know the generall goodneſſe of my people,
The duty, and the truth, the ſteadfaſt honeſtie,
And am aſſur'd they would as ſoone turne devils
As Rebells to allegeance, for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Here needs no wars.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I pray forgive us ſir.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Good Generall forgive us, or uſe your ſword,
Your words are double death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good noble Generall.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Pray ſir be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Weep out your ſhames firſt,
Ye make me foole for companie: fie Souldiers,
My Souldiers too, and play theſe tricks: what's he there?
Sure I have ſeen his face too; yes, moſt certaine
I have a ſon, but I hope he is not here now,
'Would much reſemble this man, wondrous neare him,
Juſt of his height and making too, you ſeeme a Leader.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good ſir, do not ſhame me more: I know your anger,
And leſſe then death, I looke not for.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You ſhall be my charge ſir, it ſeemes you want foes,
When you would make your friends your Enemies:
A running bloud ye have, but I ſhall cure ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Good ſir—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more good Lord: beate forward Souldiers:
And you, march in the reare, you have loſt your places. Ex.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You ſhall not be thus ſullen ſtill, with me ſiſter
You doe the moſt unnobly to be angry,
For as I have a ſoule, I never touch'd her,
I never yet knew one unchaſt thought in her:
I muſt confeſſe, I lov'd her: as who would not?
I muſt confeſſe I doated on her ſtrangely,
I offer'd all, yet ſo ſtrong was her honour,
So fortifi'd as faire, no hope could reach her,
And whilſt the world beheld this, and confirmd it,
Why would you be ſo jealous?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good ſir pardon me,
I feele ſufficiently my follies pennance,
And am aſham'd, that ſhame a thouſand ſorrowes
Feed on continually, would I had never ſeen her,
Or with a clearer judgement look'd upon her,
She was too good for me, ſo heavenly good ſir,
Nothing but heaven can love that ſoule ſufficiently, Enter Burris.
Where I ſhall ſee her once againe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more teares,
If ſhe be within the Dukedome, wee'l recover her:
Welcome Lord Burris, faire newes I hope.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: Moſt faire ſir,
Without one drop of bloud theſe wars are ended,
The Souldier coold againe, indeed aſham'd ſir,
And all his anger ended.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where's Lord Archas?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not far off ſir: with him his valiant ſon,
Head of this fire, but now a priſoner,
And if by your ſweet mercie not prevented,
I feare ſome fatall ſtroke. Drums.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I heare the drums beate,
Welcome, my worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand where ye are ſir,
Even as you love your Country, move not forward,
Nor plead for peace, till I have done a juſtice,
A juſtice on this villaine; none of mine now,
A juſtice on this Rebell.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O my Brother.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: This fatall firebrand—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forget not old man,
He is thy ſon of thine owne bloud.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: In theſe veines
No treacherie e're harbour'd yet, no mutinie,
I ne're gave life to lewd and headſtrong Rebels.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: 'Tis his firſt fault.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not of a thouſand ſir,
Or were it ſo, it is a fault ſo mightie,
So ſtrong againſt the nature of all mercie,
His mother were ſhe living, would not weep for him,
He dare not ſay he would live.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I muſt not ſir,
Whilſt you ſay 'tis not fit: your Graces mercy
Not to my life appli'd, but to my fault ſit,
The worlds forgiveneſſe next, laſt, on my knees ſir,
I humbly beg,
Do not take from me yet the name of father,
Strike me a thouſand blowes, but let me dye yours.
