sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He moves my heart: I muſt be ſuddaine with him,
I ſhall grow faint elſe, in my execution;
Come, come ſir, you have ſeen death; now meet him bravely.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hold, hold I ſay, a little hold, conſider
Thou haſt no more ſons Archas to inherit thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I have another, and a nobler:
No treaſon ſhall inherit me: young Archas
A boy, as ſweet as young, my brother breeds him,
My noble brother Briskie, breeds him nobly,
Him let your favour find: give him your honour.
sp.stage: Enter Putskie (alias Briskie) and Alinda (alias Archas.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Thou haſt no child left Archas, none to inherit thee
If thou ſtrikſt that ſtroke now: behold young Archas;
Behold thy brother here, thou bloudy brother,
As bloudy to this ſacrifice as thou art:
Heave up thy ſword, and mine's heav'd up: ſtrike Archas,
And I'le ſtrike too, as ſuddenly, as deadly:
Have mercy, and I'le have mercy: the Duke gives it,
Looke upon all theſe, how they weep it from thee,
Chooſe quickly, and begin.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: On your obedience,
On your allegeance ſave him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Take him to ye, Soul. ſhout.
And ſirha, be an honeſt man, ye have reaſon:
I thanke ye worthy Brother; welcome child,
Mine owne ſweet child.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why was this boy concealed thus?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Your graces pardon:
Fearing the vow you made againſt my brother
And that your anger would not only light
On him, but find out all his familie,
This young boy, to preſerve from after danger,
Like a young wench, hether I brought; my ſelfe
In the habit of an ordinarie Captaine
Diſguis'd, got entertainement, and ſerv'd here
That I might ſtill be ready to all fortunes:
The boy your Grace tooke, nobly entertain'd him,
But thought a Girle, Alinda, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Stand away,
And let me looke upon him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My young Miſtris?
This is a ſtrange metamorphoſis, Alinda?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your graces humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hether ſiſter:
I dare yet ſcarce beleeve mine eyes? how they view one another?
Doſt thou not love this boy wel?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I ſhould lye elſe,
Truſt me, extreamely lye ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Didſt thou never wiſh Olimpia,
It might be thus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: A thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here take him:
Nay, do not bluſh: I do not jeſt; kiſſe ſweetly:
Boy, ye kiſſe faintly boy; heaven give ye comfort;
Teach him, he'l quickly learne: there's two hearts eas'd now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You do me too much honour ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No Archas,
But all I can, I will; can you love me? ſpeake truly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes ſir, dearly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hether Viola, can you love this man?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I'le do the beſt I can ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Seale it Burris:
Wee'l all to Church together inſtantly:
And then a vſe for boyes; ſtay, bring Boroskie. Enter Boroskie
I had almoſt forgot that lumpe of miſchiefe.
There Archas, take the enemie to honour,
The knave to worth: do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then to my ſword againe; you to your prayers;
Waſh off your villanies, you feele the burthen.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Forgive me ere I die, moſt honeſt Archas;
'Tis too much honour that I periſh thus;
O ſtrike my faults to kill them, that no memorie,
No blacke and blaſted infamy heareafter—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, are ye ready?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And truly penitent, to make your way ſtraight?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Thus I waſh off my ſins.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stand up, and live then,
And live an honeſt man; I ſcorne mens ruin's:
Take him againe, Sir, trie him: and beleeve
This thing wil be a perfect man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I take him.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And when I faile thoſe hopes, heavens hopes faile me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You are old: no more wars Father:
Theodore take you the charge, be Generall.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: All good bleſſe ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And my good father, you dwell in my boſome,
From you riſe all my good thoughts: when I would think
And examine time for one that's fairely noble,
And the ſame man through all the ſtraights of vertue,
Upon this ſilver booke I'le looke, and read him.
Now forward merrily to Hymens rights,
To joyes, and revels, ſports, and he that can
Moſt honour Archas, is the nobleſt man. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: VVE need not noble Gentlemen to invite
Attention, preinſtruct you who did write
This worthy Story, being confident
The mirth joyn'd with grave matter, & Intent
To yeild the hearers profit, with delight,
Will ſpeake the maker: and to do him right,
Would aske a Genius like to his; the age
Mourning his loſſe, and our now widdowed ſtage
In vaine lamenting▪ I could adde, ſo far
Behind him the moſt moderne writers are,
That when they would commend him, their beſt praiſe
Ruins the buildings which they ſtrive to raiſe,
To his best memory, ſo much a friend
Preſumes to write, ſecure 'twill not offend
The living that are modeſt, with the reſt
That may repine he cares not to conteſt.
This debt to Fletcher paid; it is profeſt
By us the Actors, we will do our beſt
To ſend ſuch favouring friends, as hether come
To grace the Scane, pleas'd, and contented home.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: TThough ſomething well aſſur'd, few here repent
Three houres of pretious time, or money ſpent
On our endeavours, Yet not to relye
Too much upon our care, and induſtrie,
'Tis fit we ſhould aske, but a modeſt way
How you approve our action in the play.
If you vouchſafe to crowne it with applauſe,
It is your bountie, and you give us cauſe
Hereafter with a generall conſent
To ſtudy, as becomes us, your content.
